replies.text: Incredible stat from Bloomberg The cumulative sales of Ozempic Wegovy sold by Novo Nordisk have surpassed the cumulative RD spent by the company since 1995. In graph form Compared to other big pharma companies, NVO spends relatively little on RD 12 vs Mercks 30 or Pfizers 17. Basically they hit the jackpot they allocated half the share of revenue to RD as their peers, and in the span of a couple years, paid for nearly 30 years of RD on everything. At 570B, the market cap of NVO a Danish company is more than the GDP of Denmark. Though market caps and GDP are not comparable, to be clear one is valuation of all future profits, the other is the value of annual production But consider this Denmarks GDP grew 1.8 in 2023 and much of its boost is owed to the pharmaceutical industry. Without pharmaceuticals, the agency says, the countrys GDP would have instead fallen 0.1. Denmark is a shining example of Size doesnt matter. Though credit to the US for getting so obese that such a market opportunity came about While Im here sharing cool charts, heres a nice graphic of YTD market cap changes of the top 20 semiconductor companies

Very interesting numbers. I think its worth pointing out though that the amount spent isnt necessarily an accurate reflection of the effort and productivity of the RD, so not necessarily true that Novo Nordisk got lucky. For one, RD costs tend to be higher in the US. And there is the phenomenon of Nordic countries producing a high amount of innovation per capita. This could probably translate to a high level of innovation per spent, or a higher level of efficiency and productivity. The reasons for this possibly differences in work culture and management as well as any number of social differences that may play a role. Maybe the US culture is great at throwing huge amounts of cash at big problems needed innovations and getting results via brute force but maybe not generally the most efficient or innovative per spent.

Hes a god of valuation and bottomup fundamental analysis. Unfortunately he really demonstrates his lack of understanding of how the Fed of today works. The modern Fed has enormous number of tools, facilities to influence the entire yield curve that they simply never had until just recently. They already have bought and hold more 10Ys than when even QT started. If Fed wanted, in theory they could do what Japan does and completely dominate the entire market. With so many levers like BTFP, discount window collateral requirements, they can inject liquidity at will, whenever they want to and immediately if necessary. Moreover, since IORB became a tool to set the floor on shortterm interest rates rather than buying commercial paper super short bonds, there also is no concern that Fed needs to cut to follow the market down either. All in all the only thing hes really right about is that Fed doesnt have special access to data that no one else has. Actually private participants often have more. Especially industry specific data. Therefore, if they cut that doesnt mean they see a collapse in the data we cannot. It just reflects their level of caution and desire to get it right.

One of the few times his take didnt make sense to me. His point was that the Fed doesnt actually impact stocksinterest rates, because when they raise rates, there is little reaction in rates in the 36 months following. But it ignores the fact that rates across the economy react well in advance of the actual rate cut the impact of forward guidance. The 10 year treasury is a full percent lower than its peak and that was true even before the recent cut. If everyone is telling you months in advance the Fed is about to cut rates, why wouldnt you take this into account when offering loans? A more accurate take, though, is that the Fed isnt actually controlling rates, but rather following the rates. If the neutral rate goes up, everything goes up and so does the Fed rate, and viceversa. If they dont move with the neutral rate, economy either overheats or falls apart. And there are also big leverage FX markets stuff. Like when At its twoday policy meeting, the BOJ voted to increase its shortterm policy rate target to 0.25 from a range of 0 to 0.1 and the Japanese markets temporarily imploded. Just 15 basis points from effectively 0 interest rates.
I dont think Fed is an acronym is it? Isnt just an abbreviation for The Federal Reserve? Although I bet I could come up with some funny ones.

Its terrible but in terms of stock market threat, youre going to have to weather much bigger issues than this if you want to play long term. If you sell every time the news warns of global economic problems unrest its probably not going to work out so well. There will unfortunately continue to be natural disasters, social unrest, or more vague macroeconomic threats. You have to figure out your risk tolerance and whether you want to play the stock market game. Many people have had a gut feeling every day in the stock market since inception that this is going to be the month it all comes crashing down. This is the right take. The problem is that obesity rates skyrocketed in the past half century. Food industry knew how to make profits with fast, packaged and processed foods. They knew what people bought more of added sugar, fats etc. Then all the nutritional misinformation in the past few decades confused people. The true fix to the obesity epidemic is not to become obese then take drugs. The true fix is education, accessibility and affordability of nutritionally balanced food and active lifestyle for bones and muscle.

Youre right, Im very weary of all this proclamation of it being a miracle drug. One known issue is that its not suitable for pregnant people. Birth defects have been found in animal studies. If planning to prescribe this drug as a cure to obesity, it will be prescribed incredibly widely. People will be told not to take it when pregnant of course but people dont always know right away when they get pregnant or plan it so this is a pretty big concern for me with such a widely used drug. Aside from this, drugs in general are still so crude. We know they do the thing they do and and what molecular pathway they use, and generally that they dont cause you to develop some horrible disease in the short term, but we have very little grasp generally on all the other molecular pathways they potentially affect in the body and the slow, long term health impacts, especially with brand new drugs like this.
Drugs manage the symptoms they dont truly fix the root cause. An exgirlfriend who was a nurse actually told me that.

Saying obesity is solved with diet and exercise is like saying depression is solved with nature walks and perspective. Or that ADHD people just need to focus more. While some people can pull themselves out of it, there are many who will need medical intervention to deal with clinical depression. The way the brain and gut are wired makes obesity often times fall into the same category. So I would be extremely weary in calling it a choice before this drug unless you are comfortable with saying depressed people just need to choose to be happy, too.
Well, the choice will be much easier to make now.

No, not at all. Once someone is depressed, it is very hard to get out of. I have personal experience with this. However, why is there so much more depression now than other since was? Is that because if medical changes? Probably not. Theres probably something going on that is causing more depression and and of you fix that non medical cause, you eliminate the need for later medical intervention in the future. Same with health. If you dont let people get obese in the first place, its much easier to stay thin. So if we changed our food and activity inputs, it would eliminate the need for later medical treatment. Even with depression, medical treatment is usually not enough. Antidepressants are usually accompanied with therapy and lifestyle changes. Obesity and health should be viewed similarly. Thinking that a pill alone can make people healthy seems to be a pipedream. It might help lose weight, but theres more to health than just weight.

Its the other way around. It saves money which is bad for insurance companies. replies.text: Apples and Oranges. To me, Uber is no different from what Fiverr or eBay is for freelancing or physical goods. Just a middle man between service provider and consumer. NFLX, on the other hand, has content licensing, and gives a stage to independent studios. Its performance long term depends on what blockbusters new seasons would come out next, e.g. Stranger Things, Squid game, etc.

I think both of these companies are destined to fail. Whatever you do short term is on you, but these arent long term companies. Uber is going to get roasted by Lyft and local services. Netflix lacks the kind of trash TV fodder that Hulu and Paramount have a ton of, and thats essential to hold normies. Nobody gives a shit about The Circle, they want legit Big Brother. Netflix also is the most annoying about account sharing, which nerfs their contents general exposure. Due to the way they are about this my mom, my finance, my sister, and my dad all bring reviews of HuluParamount content to their social circles. Only my mom has access to Netflix, so only her social circle hears about it. Long term apply that concept nationwide. Dont bother with either. There are tens of thousands of other companies, and youre a few years late for the best window of time on these.

I dont think Uber still makes a profit, plus they treat their contractors like garbage. Which has resulted in constant expensive lobbying and litigation. Netflix seems to have been able to figure out how to keep pivoting, such as from a DVD mailing service to digital video streaming service. I dont know how they treat their employees, but havent heard anything negative, so between the two, I would choose Netflix.

Both. thousands more in totalmarket indexbased lowcost funds. Buying individual stocks or sector funds creates unnecessary uncompensated risk I avoid doing so. Index funds are boring, but better for making money. If I wanted to talk about my interesting investments at parties or wanted a new hobby, I might invest 510 of my portfolio in individual stocks. As it is, I own pretty much every publiclytraded company in the world thats interesting enough for me. All of the individual stocks sector funds are being followed by thousands or millions of other investors. Current prices reflect their collective knowledge of future expectations for each one. Im a member of the Triple Nine Society, but Im not smarter than all of them. If I found a stock or sector that looked like a bargain, the most likely explanation would be that the others know something I dont.

They are involvedplugged in with googles waymo self driving cars, have their freight operation although was getting some bad feedback for awhile, but seems like they are solving problems internally and externally in that arena and at some point will be handling automated transports, are connected with future and ready for evtols which should greatly impact people and goods transportation. Netflix is a great company, solid stats though and honestly havent researched them enough to know how bright their future looks. I think potential exists if they can expand beyond the standard platform hosting showsvideo game content and get into maybe some of the virtual reality and ai generated content space with users maybe? But my opinion fwiw is that Uber has a lot of room to grow profits as a logistics broker that is forward leaning and visionary.

Theres no debate. Not all risks are created equal. The risk of investing in individual stocks is an uncompensated risk. The risk is higher but the expected returns are not. Since theres no benefit to taking such risk, its unnecessary, as I mentioned in my previous reply. Imagine that I offer to give you some money. The amount I give you will depend on what happens when you flip a coin. You can either flip the coin once for 10,000 or you can flip it 100 times for 100 each time. Either way, the expected return is 5,000. The single flip is very risky because theres a 50 chance youll win nothing. Uncompensated risk. The 100 flips are a lot safer because youre pretty likely to get about 5000. BTW, investing in stocks instead of saving in a HYSA, etc. is a compensated risk. Risks are higher but so are expected returns.

Again, not going to debate index vs individual stocks. Each person has their own style and you can also do both. Even for individual stocks, there are growth vs value. You can create your own post to talk about it. No need off talk in this post. I am asking specific question. If you dont know or not interested, thats ok. Just go to other posts

replies.text: Most people are going to suggest an index fund that either mimics the performance of the SP 500 or the total US market andor the total world markets. You pay a fee to whoever manages that index ideally the fee is as low as possible. In your case, tax consequences are probably more important than your general person since you were able to cash flow so much in a relatively short time period. 1. Do you have a solo 401k? This should be a way to tax protect your investments andor contributions 2. Do you have a SEP IRA? Depending on how your businesses are structured you may be able to have your businesses match your inputs and provide matching funds for your employees with tax benefit upfront for your businesses. Youd want to discuss this with an accountant that specializes in business taxes because you may be able to contribute a lot of money to tax protected accounts for yourself and some or all of your employees who are interested with tax savings for yourself. 3. You could also likely use a traditional IRA the contribution limits will be on the lower end, but you might as well if you dont have one yet. Frankly, it sounds like you make enough money that it would be useful for you to retain a financial advisor find one that is a fiduciary NOT a sales person and a tax accountant its likely youre making enough money that these things would actually be useful to you.

Depends what youre looking for and your risk tolerance and how much cash youre looking to place. My big assumption is that since you bought a business, youre less interested in the conventional route of working and investing in a retirement account for 40 years. You probably went the entrepreneurial route because you wanted a different lifestyle. IF that assumption is true, Id look into passive positions in real estate deals. Specifically commercial. Ive just invested my millionth dollar into deals and its given me a much better lifestyle than conventional methods. Im 31 and workoptional from the passive income after about 10 years of investing.
Go talk a CFP for ideas. Diversification is secret of not blowing your account.

Mandatory I am not a financial advisor. In your position, I would split my extra money between index funds and reinvesting in your own business. Of course your first priority should be becoming debtfree. Pretty silly to invest in something with a 10 ROI when youre still paying on a credit card with 15 interest. Same goes for the business, if it has debt. If you have a mortgage on your business building, paying that down will increase your equity and save you interest costs long term. Obviously check with your accountant as to the tax implications. Index funds do indeed let you invest in the whole market. The market as a whole has its ups and downs sometimes big ones but long term youre looking at around 10 average gains before inflation. Inflation adjusted average ROI is around 7. 25 years is definitely looking long term. As to your business Imagine for a minute that its not your business. Now imagine that youre a newly minted MBA who just got hired to manage the business. What changesinvestments are you going to suggest to the Csuite folks? The nice part here is, as you are going to be investing your own money, youre not going to be leveraged on those investments. So if a particular investment doesnt work out, you wont be getting any upsetting phone calls from the bank manager. Lastly, my Granddad taught me this There are two kinds of bosses. Imagine youre pushing a wheelbarrow. The first kind is walking behind you cracking a whip and screaming at you to move faster. The second kind is out ahead of you, opening gates and throwing planks across ditches. Make sure your business only has the second kind of bosses. People dont quit jobs they quit managers. And when employees quit, its always the best that leave the deadwood stays. Good luck with both your business and your investing.

Lots of great advice from peeps who know a lot more than me, but for a threefund approach that you mentioned, you can go Boglehead style and invest in a total US stock market fund, total international market fund, and a total bond market fund. This can be done via mutual funds or ETFs. Just periodically adjust your contributions to maintain your target investment ratios across the three, according to your risk tolerance and preference for growth vs maintaining value, according to your goals andor retirement horizon.

Largecap US stocks SP 500 can be a great investment, but theyre not a complete retirement portfolio. Other assets should be included, such as smallercap US stocks, international stocks, bonds. Investing can be simple, but its not as simple as buying one fund suggested by SGOTI. has some great free resources to learn about investing. After a few hours reading the articles, and, especially, watching the Bogleheads Philosophy videos, most beginners can learn how to get better results than most professionals. Bogleheads is named after John Bogle, founder of Vanguard. I retired at 57 years old. Investing doesnt have to be complicated or costly to be successful simple inexpensive is most effective. I invest 100 in totalmarket, indexbased, lowcost mutual funds. Specifically, I use mostly Vanguards Total Stock Market, Total Bond Market, Total International Stock Market, Total International Bond Market funds. Ive been investing this way for 35 years. Its effective, simple, inexpensive. My asset allocation ratios of the funds mentioned is based on my need, ability, willingness to take risks. Market conditions are not a factor. Vanguards investor questionnaire personal.vanguard.comusFundsInvQuestionnaire helps me determine my asset allocation. Buying individual stocks or sector funds creates unnecessary uncompensated risk I avoid doing so. Index funds are boring, but better for making money. If I wanted to talk about my interesting investments at parties or wanted a new hobby, I might invest 510 of my portfolio in individual stocks. As it is, I own pretty much every publiclytraded company in the world thats interesting enough for me. All of the individual stocks sector funds are being followed by thousands or millions of other investors. Current prices reflect their collective knowledge of future expectations for each one. Im a member of the Triple Nine Society, but Im not smarter than all of them. If I found a stock or sector that looked like a bargain, the most likely explanation would be that the others know something I dont. I prefer mutual funds, but ETFs could also work well. The differences are usually trivial for a longterm investor, especially if theyre the Vanguard funds I mentioned above. Actually, the Vanguard funds I mentioned above have both traditional mutual fund shares ETF shares they both represent a piece of the same fund. The funds I use comprise Vanguards target date funds and LifeStrategy funds these are excellent choices for many investors. Using the component funds allows some flexibility that can have tax benefits, but also creates the need for me to rebalance them periodically. Expense ratios are slightly higher than for the components but are well worth it for many investors. Other companies have funds similar to the ones I own that would work well. I prefer Vanguard because theyve been the leader in this type of investing for decades because Vanguards customers are also Vanguards owners. I hope that helps! Id be happy to help w further questions. Best wishes!

I would invest the money for two purposes. Invest for passive income, and build a savings for emergency cash needs. The passive income is to provide enough money to cover all of your living expenses Food, Clothing, housing, utilities, Medical insurance, and taxes. . That means investing in stock and bonds for a steady stream of income. That way if the buisness has a couple of bad years you still have money for living expenses . Eventually you could be able to separate your finances from the companies expenses . You will pay taxes on the dividend income I use These ETFs for this purpose. SCHD, VYMI, Pffd, FAGIX, JEPQ, and PBDC. Split money equally between these funds. And build up the amount until it reaches your passive income goal. For savings buy growth stocks that dont pay a dividend. These will not generate any tex until you sell them. You could also invest in ETFs that pay a minimal dividend like SCHG. A growth fund that has a di ivdend of 0.5. I you are ok with slightly higher dividend you could add some low cost index fund, like BVOO or VTI. This way you could eventually have several years worth of income saved up in low tax invesmts. Additionally you could have 12 a year of cash on hand that could ba accessed in a day or less with a debit card. This money could be used to rebuild the business should it be destroyed by fire or some sort of natural disaster. Eventually you could set up a second account for your buisness. Eventually completely separating your finances form your business finances.

SPIC insured and meets regulations as much as just about any other brokerage. I got a pretty sizable bonus myself and invested it right away. replies.text: When it comes to picking ETFs or mutual funds, start with a few key factors look at their performance history, expense ratios, and the underlying assets. Tools like Morningstar or ETF.com can help you compare options easily. Also, dont hesitate to check out reviews or forums for personal experiences. Its all about narrowing down what aligns with your goals. Good luck

Personally, I do not consider every possible ETF there are more than enough choices with the big three providers plus Blackrock and maybe State Street. Decide whether your preference is high current yield vs high dividend growth rates. I invest 5050 i.e. 2 ETFs. Look at the overlap with the SP 500 and top 10 holdings. For example, I want diversification and dont want the same tech concentration. Look at the expense ratios but if you stick to the large providers mentioned above, most will be very low. Look at their total returns I look at the last 5 years.

Whats your average return over the last 20 years?

Dont be an a s s. Im actually explaining how almost all earnings plays work out and using PM as a recent example. Ive done it since 2006. The track record is enormous. Its a greater than 80 probability they work out this way and its reflected in the options pricing. For the people here its simply that I see time and again a perplexing question by people of earnings were good but why did the price go down? And every time its very obviously written in what the betting was before earnings. For instance the price was rising into earnings and then drops suddenly on good earnings. All it means is that everyone lost and the price probably is landing at a break even between long and short bets on the earnings. Its very hard to make money on a short consistently. So usually a down move is to a break even point where shorts made no money and longs get wiped out. Longs who hold do inevitably make SOME return eventually so they tend to get punished more. Their own behavior causes this since most longs tend to increase cost basis routinely keeping it close to the 20 day moving average.

No because something like 40 of the time on average a companys price will fall on good earnings. Thats the point of this thread. Earnings itself has little to do with it it has to do with positioning by traders on the results of the earnings. Too bullish of a bet on strong earnings can result in a collapse in price.
interesting rationale. but what youre doing isnt investing but just capitalizing, i.e. betting, on markets movements. thanks for sharing.
Also look up Kelly Criterion. Its another foundational point.

Investing is a bet its a meaningless distinction. Are you suggesting you know what the price of KO or MSFT will be tomorrow? By definition if you suggest investing means knowing something then you are saying you have an edge on the market. Then why dont you time the market? See my point? Youll do better if you stop thinking investing is somehow different from speculation or gambling. Its all the same exact thing. Where people get tripped up is how do they manage their buying power and cash flows. Im not being philosophical Literally all investment is the same as gambling, mathematically. So why would you cut your arms and legs off when trying to swim because this method is betting and that method is not betting? Its a false choice.

Also if you want proof of what I say then read Safe Haven. It goes into the math of how all investments are gambling and that returns can be slanted in our favor through proper bet sizes. Safe Haven is a gold standard in portfolio construction so thinking like theres a difference between investing and gambling is probably holding you back.

in my eyes, the bsic concept of investing is an educated decision based on value, risk, and whatever else variables that are deemed important by the investor. its not a speculation or bet on market movements. the concept of investing has mutated due to derivatives tradings.

Ive given you two very long posts so the take away is this...Ive done this for 20 years, I know exactly what Im talking about. The fact that youre wrong is why your returns are weak. Dont be discouraged by all these ldiots on here downvoting me. I know mountains more about this than they do and youre getting an Ivy League education about this for free because I sit on a boat with a satconnection and nothing better to do at sea lol

Lets tear this apart a bit. Can you even define risk? How can you define a thing but not actually really know what it is. For instance is there systemic risk in owning one stock? Yes or no? The actual answer is no theres no such risk whatsoever owning an individual stock. Another example question. Is being 5x leveraged 5x more risky than being 1x leveraged? The answer is surprisingly, no. In fact through the use of options we can cater risk such that we take on large amounts of risk example 5x with much less risk than a cash investor. The trick here, why its confusing, is because the word risk doesnt actually mean anything. Theres other words used by professionals to explain these concepts and explain whats happening. All of it is investing. Youre paid to take risk. If you arent buying risk youre not getting paid, its as simple as that. No one is going to pay you money for free. And this has been a lesson in why theres a lot more to it, and why Investing is the same as gambling. Its the acquisition of risk and managing that risk. Since we cant control an outcome and the market is arguably random, proven by the fact that all options at the money are priced at 5050 outcomes random walk theory the only thing we can control is how to manage risk. So investment is a management of risk. Which is in other parlance, gambling. Because gambling is 100 managing risk.

I packed a ton of concepts in my other post but I also wanted to touch on derivatives. Derivative trading has been around since the 1600s. If you include discounted bills from banks then it goes back to the 1100s. So what exactly do you think has changed because of derivatives? Are you saying there was a time that investment was more pure and less risky? Derivatives are an instrument to trade risk. Examples If I buy a stock at price 100 but I cannot tolerate a price of 95 due to financing, I will sell my risk by buying a put. I want you to drill that into your head. SELL risk by BUYING a put. A person BUYS risk by SELLING a put. These derivative transactions allow a controller in a company shareholder to offload risk without losing control of their company. They can insure their risk to an insurer the same way a driver of a car insures their driving, or a homeowner insures their house. Buying a call ALSO sells your risk to a counterparty who is insuring your position. This is why most retail who buy calls to be bullish actually lose big, and where I diverge completely from the Options Council in their advice. They the options council is completely backward in explaining their own product. The reason they are backward is that on paper the math suggests that you take on risk by buying a call, because you own rights to buy shares. But the problem is they are backward in their thinking, as stated previously you are PAID TO TAKE RISK. You cant say that you reduce risk by buying puts and then say you add risk by buying a call. I can demonstrate this fact. A synthetic long is a long call AND a short put. The short put is BUYING risk youre paid to take on risk. So what is the long call? If it were also buying risk then the risk profile would be magnified infinitely with infinite downside potential. So a longcall MUST also be a hedge sells risk and it in fact is selling risk. Selling a call is buying risk that means the majority of longcall traders are shortsellers who need to hedge their downside the higher price action.
Did you attend MIT or did you attend an Ivy? Now youre just making shit up.

yeah, people who disagreed and just downvoted wout comments are most likely dont have valid reasons to justify their stance. i appreciated the insight to your strategy. im always open to the strategies of others, as there are many ways to skin a cat. im not concerned with short term market movements theyre only noises. in fact, i always look forward to take advantage of big noises.

Theres also a rule here you are paid for buying risk. Theres a reason buying stock GENERALLY works out to barely breakeven after inflation. Buying stock, like buying a call, is actually selling risk. You are reducing risk in your portfolio by holding shares. Its the sale of the shares that assumes a tail risk which is where people confusingly think they are making money. Its not buy high and sell low. Its buy risk and sell it for a profit. Thinking backward will improve your returns. Vocabulary lesson Tail risk. Look it up. In bond parlance we call it creating convexity. Vocabulary lesson Convexity. These things are why your definition of investment vs speculation vs gambling are so nonsenscial. Its not your fault, but who would ever teach you any of this crap? How would you ever know? How can you learn to guarantee a 12 return then leverage it to 3x so you get a 36 annualized return almost guaranteed, if no one ever teaches you these things? You think Wall Street is a multitrillion industry because its gambling? The very term gambling itself is misused by the plebs, the know nothings, the retail.

Its not that they are short term or long term movements, though. Think of it this way if something is at value 100, and in 30 years itll be value 1000. Lets say you buy in at value 100. When do you ADD to that position? In every circumstance adding to that position reduces the return on invested capital. It LEVERAGES the trade because you can get a bigger overall return that is to say it is scalar. But, it reduces the return on capital. Youll never have a more advantageous time to buy than at 100. So, we have to be tactical in when to buy into positions because in the grand scheme its the ONLY advantage we have. If you dont time the market you have the worst possible outcome at large scale or the best possible outcome at small scale. Both situations are suboptimal and result in retiring at 70 with colon cancer so you have just enough to lose all your money to chemo.
Hell how do you guarantee an outcome from a proven random event? LOL. All of this comes from understanding one thing. WE ARE PAID TO TAKE RISK.
These comments make very little sense but all I want to know is how you get 36 annual returns guaranteed.

See in this way people can get rich because their money scaled with the growth of an enterprise. And thats valid. But youll never invest your way into that success. That is literally luck, because we dont really know what will happen. Elon Musk could die tomorrow and TSLA would literally go in the toilet bankrupting millions of shareholders. We just dont know. There are ways to mitigate it but we dont know. Investing your way to success is entirely different than getting lucky on a good hunch or a good company. Actually taking any product, such as gold, or the SPY, and trading it and investing it to get richer requires understanding what I just posted above. That we need to time the market. That it can be done, and that theres a difference between compounding and scaling. Leveraging a trade can be called scaling. Not everything can compound you cant compound roulette.
Yeah because smart money sells risk to dumb money.

An example the one I was referring to was the current volatility carry trade. Called The Great Carry Trade. Look up Its really a shame Im butchering my explanations so much because everyone here must think Im a clown but Im right about what I say. Its just hard to explain easily. Anyway currently and has been true for about 15 years now The Great Carry Trade has generated about a 12 guaranteed return. And the scale of the downsides means you can basically put a 3x leverage on that. Guaranteeing a 36 return annum at scale. Its, broadly speaking a calendar spread suppressing volatility. You can see it generally play out in SVIX. Because VIX spiked to 40 in Aug4 you can see that SVIX has not returned as much as it should have since VIX fell back to 18. This is because the Great Carry Trade that defines our age is suppressing volatility. The SVIX did not pull back as much as it should have short volatility when volatility spiked. A way of thinking about that is digging a tunnel through a mountain to the other side. Price is at one elevation on the west side of the mountain and you tunnel through to the same price on the east side of the mountain. This matters because for someone who could lose everything at the mountain peak now they lose nothing. As a result youre seeing the effects of the Great Carry Trade in real time play out in SVIX. Its just an example. How do you unlock this trade? Easier said than done for retail. Banks are doing it over the counter with contracts that start at 1.5billion per contract. If I can dig up an example of that I would I had one before. The reason isnt so straight forward. Its not an ETF you buy into because markets dont work that way. The banks are offsetting losses DUE to volatility by suppressing volatility rolling it out in theory in perpetuity. The conclusion of the book is that if the volatility suppression were to ever break down wed have some real financial problems on our hands. But for now, thats not an issue. Until then, its the 1920s. Make money while you can. By 1929 put it in gold or cigarettes. Something that everyone will need when the smoke evaporates.
So its guaranteed until something breaks and then it blows up? Whats the trade if you were to do this on your own, is it various options strategies like short vol straddles or something different?

I rewrote this 3x each time starting focused then going down big rabbit holes. In short, no these are custom products that banks want and pay for because they need to avoid these huge spikes in volatility. They need to build tunnels. They pay the tunnel builders. Those builders usually need to create custom products because inevitably everything comes back to control. Someone wants to be paid in control of a company or a large amount of collateral fiat currency or now, bitcoin, etc. Money doesnt mean anything to anyone with power. Control is all that matters.

The basic product is built on the backs of 0DTE options trading which the BIS estimate has a minus yes minus 31,000 return annualized. Its funny so many people act like or think like they are getting rich on 0DTE when all they are doing is fueling a complex product they arent even allowed to participate in. They are literally lumps of coal being thrown into the furnaces to fire the boilers that these big bankers are generating returns from. Any time such a strategy underperforms the market the money is going somewhere, clearly not into the hands of the retailers playing the casino.

Youll see here an example of UBSs retail facing product from 2018 as advertised. It sounds like a simple naked short strangle, but the result is a near net0 return which is a perfect hedge. This is smooth, no volatility. Which means this can be added or subtracted to a portfolio to lock in an equity value. Banks seek yield from delivering these kind of results to people who need them. Someone who cant afford volatility. Which is why I think volatility is a near meaningless measurement now. Its whatever the market maker needs it to be to explain a price after supposed fixed constants dont explain the price. It doesnt mean the system is coming apart, it just means the priests have really added a lot of extra steps to tax market participants than they did back in the old days of commissions.

The 0DTE and its rise to prominence was born out of the need to straddle the monthly expirations where when things get illiquid you get events like Aug4th where the market unwound the yen carry trade and suffered a big hit.

If you look at the Sharpe ratio its in the toilet. So what I have been illustrating in all these long winded posts is that theres a market for buying risk. People pay to sell risk. And this type of product does exactly that, by giving the buyer almost NO risk as evidenced by the pretty much completely garbage Sharpe Ratio. A measure of risk vs. return. No risk, no return. So banks are buying risk they assume the risk others need to sell or are forced to sell. What does that look like? Short selling, borrowing shares, etc. Basically the opposite of everything retail does. Retail long buys, cashowns shares, holds forever. And retail dies poor. Because no one rewards riskless portfolios. The greatest risk in life is not taking one.

replies.text: If you sign up for free you can see the rates. Or you can just access the futures pricing directly here SOFR is slightly different than the FFR, but for all practical purposes they can be used interchangeably. All theyre doing is calculating the probabilities based on futures pricing. So it changes every day, but its rarely wrong because the Fed is intent on effectively communicating its intent to markets and uses future pricing as a proxy for how well its doing its job.
How the hell does this get downvoted? lol

The FED watch actually drastically deviates from SOFR somehow for instance it might say 30 chance of a 50bp move even though SOFR has given it a 100 chance. So I rely on SOFR but Fedwatch is ok too. The better rationale is that its rarely wrong because the Fed follows the US02Y yield. So whatever SOFR does is the market telling the Fed what to do. I think the distinction matters.
You used the word never.

The better rationale is that its rarely wrong because the Fed follows the US02Y yield. This is the most backwards understanding of expectations theory Ive ever seen put to words lmfao So whatever SOFR does is the market telling the Fed what to do. It is objectively not that. At all. You can literally track the shift in futures pricing between various statements and press conferences, as they all react to new information and sentiment shifts being communicated by the Fed.

The Fed is short for Federal Reserve, not an acronym, and doesnt need to be set in allcaps. Initialisms which may be appropriate depending on the context include FRS for Federal Reserve System or FOMC for Federal Open Market Committee. Well youre also a clown who uses Fedwatch approximates instead of SOFR actuals? But insults aside Im right and youre wrong. The Fed uses SOFR to determine what their next move should be. They say so as much and unlike you, Ive actually had a conversation with Fed officials ABOUT the aberration caused by the change from LIBOR to SOFR in the Financial Stress Index. So I can 100 tell you that the Fed follows SOFR. Period.

Lmao every single time I correct someone on some pretty simplistic mistakes, they immediately reach for insults and trust me bro, I know the real professionals nonsense. Something about people who work in finance vs those who dont, the ones who do credentialize themselves by sharing information. The ones who dont rely on insults and unsupported claims of expertise. The Fed uses SOFR to determine what their next move should be. They say so as much Can you kindly link me anywhere in a speech or what have you where anyone indicated this was the case? Ive actually had a conversation with Fed officials ABOUT the aberration caused by the change from LIBOR to SOFR in the Financial Stress Index. This is unrelated to the topic at hand, Im glad you got to ask a fun question when a governor stopped by your finance survey course though. At a basic level, SOFR is just an approximation of overnight repo rates, and overnight repo rates are almost entirely driven by the FFR because the FFR is the uncollaterized rate, the repo rate typically sits just a bit under this rate but is almost entirely driven by it. So its very very strange that your interpretation is the exact opposite, and leads me to believe that mayhap you should do a bit of studying before getting so argumentative online.
I literally have emails with Fed officials about this very thing. LOL

The crash of 1929 happened because the major banks all got together and recalled those margin loans on the same day, forcing many people to sell stock in a futile attempt to repay their loans to people like JP Morgan. The bank owners then swooped in as the market crashed and bought those same stock at bargain basement prices, knowing they could afford to hold the stock until the markets recovered. Therefore making millions while all the small investors lost their shirts. I have no idea where you got this nonsense from. The bankers buying was an attempt to stop the slide, which had been done successfully multiple times over the previous 2 decades and was essentially expected of them to try to restore confidence in the market. They didnt buy the bottom they were attempting to catch a falling knife on behalf of the markets. The main guy doing so bankrupted himself and his businessamong others. In addition, the margin calls didnt trigger the crash The margin calls were contractual and entirely based on the prices falling and traders who were trading on margin. The markets were clearly shaky and overextended more than a month prior, with some famous economists predicting it and advising investors sell and get out. Finally, even if you found some evidence that what you described was the intent, these bank owners did not make millions, many of them went bankrupt None of them turned a profit from the crash. If you have any sort of citation to back up this nonsense, please cite it. Because this is almost entirely false.

I mean that Time Warner ATT comment is a misrepresentation. Time Warner got bought by AOL in one of the worst mergers of all time. The resulting company divested several large TW assets, including TW cable which was spun off and then bought by Charter in 2016 so it wasnt even part of the company when ATT bought it. Charter stock is up less than 10 total since it bought TW cable in 2016. The remnants of TW excluding cable were then bought by ATT in 2018 l, more than 15 years after the dotcom bubble, in probably the worst merger of the last decade, before being spun off again. Now theyre been merged to form Warner Brothers Discovery, a venture that has lost about half its value since WBD and the remnants of TW merged. Time Warner did almost absolutely everything wrong over the last 20 years.

I wont get political either, but reproduction rates are influenced by so many factors. When human capital creation formal education early professional career determine so much about future wealth creation, pairing off and reproducing become deprioritised and put off. Add to the expense of keeping your childrens human capital creation, the number of children produced per couple also declines. Population structural trends become kinda simple math as we substituted low skill labour with unintelligent industrial capital with high skill quasihuman capital factors of production from 1800 to now. So.... What do you do when you need additional factor inputs to support growth? You import it. In any place other than Utah, or other tradwife cultures? I dont care how much you split the chores, that would just wreck a womans body and ability to build a career. Biology is unapologetically misogynistic. I feel like climate change is the big issue where rightwingers bury their heads in the sand, and fertility rates are the leftwing counterpart. Good question. What Id say is that the amount being dumped into AI is substantial. A single Nvidia GB200 rack is around 3MM. A data center intended to support AI is billions. The impact of this will depend upon the size of the company in question. For a small startup its obvious, the CapEx is substantial and any deviation in revenue is crippling. For the Mag 7Hyperscalers, the CapEx isnt as big of a deal since they all sit on enormous piles of cash. However, a substantial portion of their increased value over the last 2 years is heavily attributed to AI. It would stand to reason that they may have to give back some of that value if the projected revenue associated with AI doesnt come to fruition. Similarly, there will be ripples as a result of this. There are a number of Tier 1sTier 2s that are all in in supporting AI. There are dedicated hardware solutions in cabling, cooling, rack systems, etc. These systems are only necessary for 50kW racks which really only AI and HPC require. IMO, its all contingent on AI generating revenue and establishing a real ROI.

Even if AI doesnt bust, its arguably pretty well priced in relative to historic forward PE ratios. Either capital andor labour factor productivity will need to increase a lot or new even more productive industries will need to be invented to drive corporate earnings growth higher than current expectations. Theres just not enough slack in employment, willingness to open floodgates to immigration, andor receptivity to even greater trade liberalisation for US corporates to deliver en masse earnings upside surprises. This isnt to say some specific industry verticals or xcap size companies might not massively outperform expectations. The argument for exUS is that forward PEs are gentler, more productivity growth looks easily captured, working age population growth is happening, and tech incl AI might make new markets easier less expensive to serve. So take your allocation and set it and rebalance to it. Im 7030 U.S. exUS in equities as I want a slight future expense bias in my currency allocation and have nonUS currency exposure in other assets. But can see the argument for global equity weighting is just as compelling.

Your logic is lacking. Either the house is paid off X months early or the car is. Either way, youre not paying interest on the amount for X months.

That doesnt matter, wherever you put the lump sum, say its 10k, youre avoiding the 8.75 interest on that 10k. Its the same overall. You can ignore the loan period since interest is an annual rate, and since the rate is the same for both you can just combine them. If theres 20k left on the car loan and 300k left on the mortgage you owe 320k at 8.75 and a 10k lump sum payment will reduce that to 310k. What youre talking about is how payments are calculated. If you pay more on the car loan and pay it off early and then dont put that extra money from finishing the car loan early toward paying off the house. In that case, the 10k isnt really putting extra money towards the debt because youre taking it back out by pocketing the car payments you would have been making the last 2 years or whatever of the car loan. Instead of reducing the total debt by 10k, youre just shifting when its being paid. If you put the 10k toward the house now, youre still making payments on both for the full term so you paying the debt down faster.

Run it in some payoff calculator. A 5 year loan at 10 and a 30 year loan at 10. If you take 10,000 or whatever amount and put that money towards one or the other. The end total paid will be identical.
Thanks
True, will use the money freed up to pay off bits of home loan as well
You misunderstood. The things I listed, you should do, in the order I listed them.
The salient information I think is that you are IN India. We have loads of people here and probably most places with big cities who are FROM India, so that doesnt tell us much

Loans cause you to pay more interest early on and less later on. So while what youre saying is true the number of payments decreased is significantly more on a larger loan saves you more money. In other words your X is different depending on which one you give the money towards

It appears loan length matters more. 100,000 loan at 30 years Total paid without a payment made 201,589 With a 10k payment made 169.614 25,000 loan at 7 years With no payment total paid 30,052 With 10k paid 26,709 For these I used the same loan percentage just changed the loan amount and length. Source

I like the play of words.

I suppose its a behavioral issue. If one pays the car down and then later doesnt apply their car payment to the mortgage after its paid and instead adjust their lifestyle to consume it, then it matters. If, however, you dump all your unbudgeted cash into your debt, then it would make no difference. And why wouldnt you? The best solution might not be the same for everyone. If someone has a tight budget, having the car loan off their back might help avoid credit card use.

Alright yeah I said that incorrectly. Its not that the end of the term youll have paid less. You need to look at when it would have paid off and what you still owe for each. So using your numbers. 10k towards a 25k loan at 5.375 will mean you pay it off in 47 months not 7 years. At 47 months a 100k 30 year loan will have a balance of 94,153. If you pay the 10k towards the 100k instead, at 47 months the balance is 81,870. And you would have 12,174.still on the 7 year loan left. Add them together and you get the 94153. The reason it shows up as being better after 30 years, is that you stopped paying the full monthly on the 7 years, which is potentially good, but then the interest kicks in and you arent paying all the loans off at the same monthly anymore.

The way I view it is that it matters when you pay a loan off. 10k on principle at the beginning of the loan when most of what your paying is just covering interest is going to have a bigger impact than closer to when the loan is ending. At the end most of it just goes towards principle so its not saving much on the interest side Edit I could be wrong but I think the math sides with me. Specifically paying off the house first With a 30 loan the savings on interest are way higher for a single payment

Youre looking at it as 2 loans because there are two minimum payments and two terms. Im looking at it as one 30 year loan with a minimum payment equal to the sum of the two individual minimum payments because there is no sensible place to put the former car loan payments after the that loan is paid. If it helps, consider any cash you have as cash borrowed at your highest interest rate while you have debt. You are paying interest on it by virtue of not applying it to your loan.

To reframe, in Buffets and Mungers view, its not high quality stock but high quality company. Their view iswas, theyre buying a part of a company. From experience, I dont think this is true. Mean reversion is basically the law of all markets. There is not a time horizon past which it becomes profitable on average to bet that deviations from the trend will continue. Deviation from trend is almost always highly inversely correlated with next day returns. Ive backtested the shit out of price data, and momentum strategies are absurdly rare and contrived. You might find one for every 20 working mean reversion formulations. Source Im not Jim Simons, but I do work in a hedge fund and write quant strategies.

Not a bad question. Let me break it down. Basically, the issue here that makes it difficult to make sense of comparing charts like SPY vs SPMO is that you have to adjust things by their vol. If SPMO makes more, but _only_ because its more risky, then youre not actually getting a free lunch here. Youre receiving more reward for taking more risk, but the payback will be as excessively painful as the rewards. Youre probably familiar with this concept from comparing QQQ vs SPY. We all pretty much know and agree QQQ does better for awhile bc its more volatile, but when the downturn comes, it gets smacked twice or thrice as hard. If you wanted to backtest this yourself, youd want to calculate daily returns from spy and spmo. Youd also calculate their stdev aka volatility. Then youd look at the return series return_spmovol_spmoreturn_spyvol_spy, which effectively emulates the trading strategy of going long spmo and hedging with a vol equivalent sized spy position. I tested something like this just now, i wanted to know and it has a sharpe ratio of .26, which is pretty trash, definitely not of statistical significance. If spmo was actually better than spy on a risk adjusted basis, the sharpe should be higher, like at least 1.

replies.text: the increase in price doesnt create any compounding effect. Here is where you are stuck. You are focused on the price when you should be focused on what drives the price. In an ideal world what drives the price is earnings. A wellfunctioning company operates at a profit and what does it do with that profit? Either pays it out as a dividend or reinvests it into the company which creates more growth. Naturally there are limits, but that reinvesting profits back into the company creates the compound growth in earnings which drives the same exponential growth you see in bank account compounding interest.

The mechanism of return isnt important, whether its interest, dividends or price appreciation. The compounding part is leaving the return to generate its own return. If you take out the return then it wont compound, even if it was interest because compound interests doesnt work just because you call it interest, its the compound part thats important.

lets assume 10 appreciation and some random ETF is 100 year 1 100110 gain of 10 year2 110121 gain 11 year3 121133.1 gain 12.1 Now obviously no ETF goes up 10 each year every year but the concept still works See how in year 2 your gain is 11 not 10, in year 3 its 12.1 , each year your gains grow, this is compounding , by year 25 your gains will be 100 a year

You are correct in that compounding does not really exist in equity investing. However, its sort of a semantic argument. Most people subscribe to the idea that the SP 500 averages 10 APY over time not really an idea this is historically true. Those people might say if they invest 5000 into the SP, their investment yields 10 each year and the returns compound year after year. After ten years, they have 13k from that investment. In reality, there was no compounding, per se. The value of the stock just went up 160.

Stock market growth isnt determined by math but it models it. Stocks on average increase in value as the company ears money and reinvests it for the future. Theres a huge amount of variation from investment to investment and from year to year, but in the long run the growth follows the same kind of curve you get with normal compounding investments. When people say the stock market offers compounding growth, what they really mean is stocks will increase in value over time, and the rate of increase is exponential.

Youre getting thrown by dividends and thinking of them a interest. Dividends from equities are just part of the total return, if there is no growth to provide the funds to pay the dividend you would have 0 gain. If youre reinvesting dividends it just means youre not taking that amount out of the investment. Compounding in equities is based on how we measure change, its not extra money, its just that more dollars invested returns more dollars with the same percentage increase. Growth is always a rate, an amount of change over a specific period. If you apply a rate over consecutive periods its not addition, its multiplication. 10 year for 10 years isnt 100, its 259 because its 110 of 110 of 110... You start with 100 and then its 110, 121, 133... Each time you apply the rate its to the total from last time. That doesnt mean you get more than the asset grew in that time frame. Its also why something going down 10 and then up 10 doesnt bring it back to the original amount. Compounding comes from measuring changes based on some period and then applying that to a multiple of that period.

Compounding interest determines the returns of things like interest bearing accounts, but for stocks its the opposite. Compounding is simply used as a way of representing the price increase of a equity over time so it can be compared to things like interest bearing accounts applestoapples.

Bond compounding youve got the idea. Stock compounding we usually expect a company to reinvest the bulk of its earnings in order to generate return on investment. The value of a stock is typically determined by an expectation of the present value of future cash flows same as a bond, mechanically, but different rate of return. The future cash flows of a company will be increased if the reinvested earnings result in growth of profits. Recurrent growth on base plus growth is compounding. The compounding doesnt happen in credits to your account in the form of interest but increases in your share of the cash flow generation and growth of that stream. You collect the compounded cash when you sell your equity rights to someone else. ETF think of a buying an etf as buying shares in a company that just owns shares in other companies. An ETF compounding is just the sum of all of the individual companies held by the fund. When you buy the fund you buy property rights and the sum of those rights increase as the cash flow generation from the companies in the portfolio increase. Your problem here is not that you are misunderstanding compounding, but the problem is that your understanding of how different types of financial instruments work is incomplete. Think of value as cash flows and the financial instrument as the mechanism of financial claim and youll get closer, maybe. You should try working thru a text on this, the openstax text is decent and free, and watching videos or asking social media isnt going to get you the knowledge you need to fully grasp this stuff. Once youve figured out the answer to your original question, you will need to start thinking about risk and then you can start thinking about intrinsic value.
Dividends dont compound anything. In stocks or funds its the return every year. Its variable but over time you are getting return on top of you previous returns.

Some etfs, well at least mine mostly come with interest. The good ones I reinvest. The losers I take cash dividend. As for the rest it is best for use to figure out for you as you seem to have trouble comprehending it.

Well said. For a stock, the underlying company grows, and that growth is compounded year after year. Yes, it may go down sometimes, but the overall growth goes up in general. The same holds for an ETF. The only difference is that instead of having growth in one company, the ETF holds several companies or bonds, or other assets, and each of those assets grows in a compounding manner.
This is what came to my mind.

replies.text: Cash in this context doesnt literally mean cash, it means something that cant crater in value during a downturn and is reasonably liquid. When you hear about Buffetts cash hoard it is that, not some scrooge mcduckian vault

Your cash holding is usually your emergency fund. Its the money you want to guarantee is there for emergencies, which could also include an extended period of unemployment. An emergency fund doesnt all have to be cash though. A portion of cash that is immediately accessible paired with something like a money market account with a quick settlement date for the rest that doesnt need to be available same day is a valid strategy.

I think the point youre making is just a pedantic one. It will depend on the type of underlying bonds, but in many cases people would consider bond funds or laddered short term government bonds to be a cash equivalent.

Bonds Cash Money Market Funds Bonds Cash

a year or more in cashequivalents bonds and bond funds are an equivalent. Money market funds are also. These have similar or slightly better returns than an HYSA, the instantliquid cash version. Youll see that most people say you can put your emergency fund in any of these three investments. Some people take the small amount of extra liquidity and ease of access of the savings account in exchange for the small amount of lesser returns

I readsee all advice advocating holding a year or more in cashequivalents for a market downturn and I dont get it. What the hell are you reading!? Isnt the whole POINT of holding a significant percentage of bondsbond funds is that you sell those off while your equities are down thus preserving their value until the equity value returns?...For that matter if you sell your bonds during the downturn to rebalance you can even come out ahead when the market recovers since you bought equities at a discount. I dont agree that thats the point of bonds. The benefit you get from rebalancing is smaller than the difference in expected returns between stocks and bonds. So over the long term youd come out ahead if you were 100 equities with no bonds. The real point of holding bonds is to reduce overall volatility to a degree that allows you to live through a downturn without freaking out. this last bump a couple years ago some bond funds did go down in value. But not nearly as much as equities. You must not be aware of ZROZ or EDV. They definitely lost more than equities in 22. Bonds funds can have a wide range of risk from nearly zero to nearly as volatile as stock funds. Just be careful and dont assume all bond funds are like SHY or BND. Regarding emergency fund, I feel like 1 month of expenses is too small and 12 months is too big. 36 feels about right and in a real loss of income emergency I would cut expenses to stretch it further.

No. The point of bonds are to decrease the amount of volatility in a portfolio. They arent there to sell for when you need cash. As far as an emergency fund goes, well things can add up quick. For example, you get in a car accident, and suffer injuries and have to go to the hospital. 1 month of expenses isnt going to cover that especially of your ACheater goes out in your house the next day. Keeping liquid cash is meant to cover any, and all emergencies not for something that is relatively cheap like replacing a flat tire.
Something to cover you if the downturn includes losing your job so you arent decimated.

A time frame worth of expenses generally refers to an emergency fund, is that what youre asking about? Saying you dont need an emergency fund if you have bonds? Maybe youre mixing up talk about allocation per goal and allocation per account, or overall allocation. If youre 30 you might have 10 or less in bonds in your 401k, but if youre saving to put a down payment on a house in the next couple years you overall allocation might be 80 fixed income, including mostly cash equivalents. Cash equivalents in tax advantaged accounts may be liquid, but that money isnt necessarily easily spendable.

Sounds like a person who never lost power or internet for a week, job is intact, isnt saving for an upcoming expenditure and likely uses charge cards in lieu of our grocery store which only accepts debit cards. Bonds are part of a diversified portfolio, but Ill still have a stash of liquid cash, up to 3 years worth sometimes. And then theres my mother, at 88, widowed 2 years ago and now the credit union only issued her a secured card, 5,000 limit. Were keeping enough cash in Treasury Direct and a ladder of Bills, so she can pull what she needs on short notice, such as a relocation, a car, medical. No CDs and no bonds. She doesnt need bonds for any reason.
I think the recommendation for hold a 6 months to a years worth of cash in a HYSA is in case you lose your job or something and need to use it for bills or whatever till a new job is found.

This perfect storm you talk about where equities and bonds become correlated and fall and rise together was multiple decades before 1981 bond bull. It can happen again. Some cash or shorter term bonds are never a bad idea later in life.
This is from investopedia, Generally, when inflation is high and volatile, stocks and bonds have a positive correlation. That is, their prices move in the same direction downward.

I fully agree with your conclusions here. We all know a huge portion of Americans dont even have 500 for an emergency to cover a bill I try to keep a few months of expenses in BondsTreasuries for use as you outlined. Other than that, I can put my onhand cash towards whatever pops up or use a Credit Card and just pay it off. Again, I am not clear on what small percentage of things could just pop up where I need more than a month of wages to cover the bill. My wife is also gainfully employed, so that may affect my POV for the moment... I am not saying to put all my bills on CC, but I mean you do have approx 30 days to pay that thing off. May as well use the tools at your disposal.
The Cash is to pay your rent when you lose your job. The last thing you need when youre unemployed is to be hit with capital gains taxes to pay from selling bonds.

Cash money market funds, short term bonds 2 years Bonds 230 year bonds. These will behave very differently in certain circumstances and a 3year bond very differently than a 30year bond. As with stocks, you want diversification different lengths, federal, municipal, corporate. Or just buy BND.

The idea of holding blended portfolios, bonds and equities, is that generally their performance is inversely related. They can therefore be used jointly to balance a portfolios overall volatility against macroeconomic conditions which isnt something you can fully do with just equities or just bonds, they can also be used jointly to create growthincome strategies. The reason why you still want to have cash is twofold safety net and opportunity. You always want to buy low and sell high classic right? but you cant do that if when everybody is liquidating positions when supply is high and demand is low the price is low showing that people tend to sell low and buy high you have no cash to buy in because its locked into something already. You also want a safety net if things like your job took a downturn along with the market which often happens, if the funds are locked into bonds as you suggested you wouldnt be liquid for things like expenses and to get liquid youd have to sell your bonds at a discount.
Holding bonds to sell in an equities downturn didnt work so well in 2022.
Am holding cash till after the election

Im not disagreeing with you but I can think of some reasons. If interest rates are declining and you locked in some bonds paying a good rate do you want to have to give those up in an emergency? Other way around you might be selling them for a loss. Bonds do fluctuate in value a bit so you may take a capital gainloss while with cash there was no fluctuation. Certain bonds are harder to sell and may not sell immediately.

You sound like you have a healthy concern over tail risk, black swans. which is completely reasonable and is the whole reason for having a risk off element of your portfolio. For most people, the risk off element is a bond fund or individual corporate bonds, usually investment grade. However, during a market crash which usually coincides with the recession. The ratings agencies downgrade all those corporate bonds and the value of your bonds declines markedly just as your stocks are going down leaving you with no capital to inject into your equity portfolio and to be able to buy at low prices. Warren Buffett gets around this problem by having 285 billion in Treasury bills which dont go down in value as they are short duration of only four to 13 weeks. I get around this problem by having a sizeable chunk of EDV, a vanguard thirtyyear US Treasury strip fund, such that if recession hits. Long yields fall and the underlying value of EDV goes up 25 for every 1 fall in interest rates.

replies.text: The problem is The government basically can do nothing about the structural problems.
I have been hearing about Chinas economy crashing since the early 2000s. Any day now.
To compare, US has an average ratio of 4 Really?
Investing in Chinese stocks is no panacea. Investing in US or EU you generally have reasonable accounting rules about performance and expected future earningsliabilities. That isnt a thing there.

Sure China doesnt have property tax...for NOW. There are no voters to please, so policymakers can do whatever the hell they want. If you look carefully, theyve been teasing property tax for years. And you do know that people dont actually own the land they purchase, they only rent it for 70 or 50 years.

In China you dont have 2 adults trying to buy a house, you could have up to 14 6 from each side plus the original 2 to support a new home for new weds. So 2030 ratio can still be afforded. Their parentsgrandparents also dies and each couple can inherit multiple houses. Without siblings to dilute, it a huge sum of wealth. Plus mortgages for extra spending or additional housing investments. In Chinese culture, kids arent left to fend for themselves when they turn 18. Theyre supported till death
People have been saying this for 20 years. Ill believe it when I see it
Have you lived in china?

Housing is way more plentiful in China. 93 of Chinese citizens own their own home or live with family who own it, compared to 65 in the US. They tend to live with extended family but many young people move away to big cities to get higher paying jobs and live on their own. Most of the homes in China are apartments though, not single family homes like in the US, so they should be more affordable.

China has a couple interesting issues working against their economy. 1 Falling population 2 Over counted population estimates are they over counted by as much as 100 million 3 Imbalance in age and gender of the population aka one child policies revenge! Now the surplus of males causes high competition for the available females. This causes the price of marriage to go up because now parents are looking at the wealth their daughter will get. Why approve of a marriage to a poor guy who only has two houses when we can approve of a rich guy with 4 houses? The was one cause of the housing market always seeming to continuing to raise. That has now been exposed as being founded on unstable economic policy and the housing market is more or less in the middle of a crash. 4 The youth not finding any reason to work and laying flat instead which means they are staying at home living with mom and dad which makes it less likely they will start having their own children any time soon. They are also failing to contribute to the economy which is a problem. 5 One way they were stimulating the economy was through infrastructure spending. Think of building massive cities for no one to live in or massive highways to places that dont have enough population to justify them, etc. 6 Falling tax base this one is based on the back of the falling real estate market. Since they dont have property tax how do the municipal governments get money? In the past they got money through sellingleasing land to the large builders. The same ones going bankrupt now. So now the large builders are no longer buying and the governments have a greatly diminished tax base. 7 They are attempting to use dept trap diplomacy which hasnt been a problem when their economy was doing well but now that its cooling off all of that extra cash could sure be useful. 8 Western companies pulling out and diversifying supply chains. Long story short western companies see the writing on the wall A few issues but Taiwan being one and china not being cheap anymore are two big issues and dont want to be in bed with a country these see as untrustworthy and unreliable. Check out Tesla in China for an example of how China welcomed Tesla mainly so they could emulate them and then do it cheaper. Enter BYD. I dont believe Tesla will pull out of china but they IMHO have been negatively affected by it. 9 And with less western buyers they will need to rely more and more on eastern buyers who just dont have the purchasing power at the same parity. Anyway most of what I just typed is from memory so a good chance some of its over simplified and not 100 accurate but it should hopefully add a little to the discussion.

China and all eastern asian countries have one similar structural problem, declining population. The stimulus plan may very likely work in the near run. im not selling my bidu or baba shares. it will gain in 6 months. economy isnt near collapsing yet

The Chinese have two dilemmas The leadership doesnt care about domestic consumption for economic growth either for ideological reasons or just blindness. Secondly their demographics are terminal, with very few people relative to their overall population in their prime consuming years. The Chinese government structured their economy so that the only path to wealth was HEAVILY subsidized industrial production cars, steel, buildings, apartments, roadsrails, export consumer goods, etc, and if you do start to get wealthy outside of that they smack you down. Hard. So when the country is supersaturated and there are no more buildingsroadsetc to be built that has ANY potential economic return, and nobody wants to buy your exports, AND youve killed off any interest in foreign investment by acting like a massive bag of ds to anybody notchinese then theres nothing to be done. Theyre boogered. The leadership has, with great verve and enthusiasm, along with a monster sized helping of corruption, painted themselves into a corner with no way out. replies.text: I wouldnt buy bond funds because those CAN lose principle. Buy bonds. That way even if interest rates move you get guaranteed interest rate and your principle is 100 safe. Go with T bills
I think you are not taking on enough equity risk given your rather robust retirement benefit assets.

You have a bondlike portfolio already due to the VA SS benefits. Why be even safer than that? You can model the income you receive from these as an interest payment from a bond and use that to inform your allocation. This should push you to something like 100 stock rather than 65 bond.

Am I reading it right that except for a 2 to 3 year period you wont really be spending down your portfolio in a meaningful way? And the reason is because your other benefits that kick in at age 63 will be sufficient to cover most of your expenses? I ask because I earlyretired 8 years ago starting with a 65 stake in bonds, but that extreme was necessary to bring volatility downbecause we spend the portfolio down about 3 annually for all our living expenses. If you anticipate spending down just a small fraction of your pie for living expenses, then in your shoes Id still aim for growth, yet guard against possibly unrecoverable huge drawdowns by using an asset like Treasurys that rallys when stocks tank. For example a 15 stake in longishterm Treasurys will balloon into a 20 to 23 stake in a big stock selloff. In a selloff youre already in a better position than people with 100 stock portfolios. In this example youd only have an 85 exposure to stocks. Then for a bonus, you can sell off however much of the bond position you want in order to buy more stocks at depressed prices. And because of this, when stocks recover, youll reach breakeven quicker than someone with a 100 stock portfolio. Knowing what percentage you think youll be taking out of the portfolio each year for living expenses will inform you on how to adjust your portfolios risk.
William Berstein has written that once youve won the game, you should stop playing. I think you can definitively make the case for a move to bonds given your situation. Congrats!

There definitely comes a point where capital preservation beats returns. Ill have to have a much harder think about it when I get closer to financial independence, which is probably 5 years off. I think if it were me, Id be less conservative if I already had defined benefits that probably cover most of my fixed expenses. But youre right, such decisions are very personal.
