You arent going to have to spend everything in the next few years. Frankly it seems like youre overreacting. It seems like you just cant stand the idea of the market crashing between now and when you get on social security and medicaid, which I understand, but statistically youre more likely to miss out on gains than losses during that 35 years. What retirees that I know have done which I plan to do is to make sure I have around 2 years of expenses in cash or something close to it when they first retire but leave the rest invested in a mix of stocks and fixed income. The stock market is scary and living off of your investments feels like stepping off of a plank, but there has never been a 10 year period in history where the stock market lost money, and statistically it doubles every 710 years. I use these numbers for planning purposes.

I like your positioning and reasoning, especially as it relates to tech stock pes. I also think it pays to not fight the Fed whos going in to rate cutting mode, which will benefit both bonds and your value stocks over the next year.

You are really quite young compared to how long you will likely live. Moving to such a large bond proportion so young increases the chance that youll deplete your assets too early. Im 70, with a fairly high risk tolerance, and Im at 20 bonds planning to go to 25 over the next few years.

Its such a Herculean task to forecast the elements that should drive asset allocation. I remind myself my job until I die is to adapt to my environment. With that in mind, I focus on what I can control my spending habits, the income Im likely to get from some combination of retirement income from investment income, government entitlement payments and anything else in the mix. If I have to draw down from there, I dont want it to be too steep a draw because I might last a while longer than I think. You might laugh but I also have become proficient in Spanish as there are low cost Spanish speaking places to live I know I could just be another expat and not learn, but thats not me and done some research on places for great medical care on a modest budget looking at you, India, for my next colonoscopy! so if my health declines Im able to adapt. I do wonder about bonds versus stocks, and if either one is terribly safe. But I like to bear in mind that after every payroll day, workers pound the market with a ton of 401k buying of mostly stocks. And every auction date, the government is a massive seller of new government debt that rolls higher at an increasing rate. Im not saying equities are some safe haven if bond auction failures start occurring. But over long periods of time Id rather own something that has habitual buyers coming behind me on the regular than own something there is going to be a hell of a lot more of during my retirement.

Sounds like a terrible plan and you will barely beat inflation. You already have a defined benefit retirement but the COLA raises may not meet actual spending inflation. Return of a constnat duration bonds fund can be predicted to be the yield to maturity of the fund, over the weighted duration of the fund times 2, minus 1 year. For example, BNF has a YTM of 4.43 with a weighted duration of 6 years. Thus, it will provide a 4.43 annualized return over 11 years. If bonds value goes down, its because their yields go up. So the lower valuation gets offset by higher interest income.

If youre sitting on a lump sum DCA will almost always have lower expected returns. The only benefit of DCA is lower regret if market declines in near term.
DCA is always good depending on risk appetite, and is my personal preference. But folks have been citing some backtesting that shows a lump sum typically outperforms.

DCA is about emotional management, not long term results. As soon as someone communicates any weakness in financial matters the whole conversation is shifted away from what is optimal and correct towards what minimizes their chances of making a significant mistake. For example, pulling all your money out of the market is a big mistake. So while its completely correct to put the money in right away, doing so then having a drop might trigger the scenario where they pull it out again. So its DCA in order to manage those emotions if it goes up they have a benefit, if it goes down then they successfully timed it and have a benefit from that. The best thing a person can do as an investor is to fix themself first, preferably before they get money. Then you can run everything optimally. For example if I talk to an advisor and I say I put my money in the sp 500 index fund or VTI market for the past 20 years and Ive only sold some to buy a car and do a bathroom remodel then that person knows that Ive been through multiple significant downturns and never touched it. They can leave it invested aggressively because they know I wont flinch.

replies.text: Have you considered REITs first? Owning property is often tax inefficient and can be a real headache if you are not up for the job of being a landlord

Talk to your business banker and see what they have to say. Im a commercial loan underwriter and my bank, along with just about all of them in my area, started getting a lot more restrictive on lending for rentals a couple of years ago. Obviously every bank is going to be different and it will be market dependent. Anyway, youll probably need to bring at least 25 for a down payment. Likely more if the apartments are consider 14 family which is what it sounds like. The bank will want deposits too. Deposits were a point of emphasis for just about every bank the last 2 years. My bank wont lend for a rental without at least 10 of the loan amount on deposit, for example.

REITS and owning private real estate are very different. REITS have shown to be tremendously sensitive to movements in interest rates. Private real estate is certainly impacted by changing rates but the volatility is much softer. Plus if OP is cash flowing their rentals and had locked in a rate on their loans, they arent going to see that impact where as a REIT basically marks to market every day. Even with a little dividend income from a REIT, I dont think I would put them in the same category.

Why do you use a management company when you are general contractor ? I assume you are licensed and your business is an actual working entity that has back office capabilities for paperwork and labor for actual maintenance.

this! of course its personal preference, but for me being a landlord is the last thing i want. id gladly take a lower return knowing i dont have to deal with that. and unless the location is amazing, owning real estate doesnt even return that much better than your average reit portfolio.
I think there needs to be a real want to be a landlord. Reits can get you exposure to diversified real estate, and offer more protection through the diversification.
for sure. and i dont dismiss the idea of owning physical property like real estate or land. it all has its place. but its just not for me.

It just seemed like there should be something between the HYSA bond market and the double digit swings of market or sector type funds Thats the beauty of asset allocations it doesnt have to be all or nothing. You dont have to be all shortterm cashHYSAmoney market funds, bonds CDs Treasurys etc., or equities stocks. Traditionally, something like 20 equity80 bonds is considered conservative in its investment objective. So, hypothetically, if you had 20k in a savings and would like some potential upside for a portion of it, you can allocate 4k into a wide market index like VOOVTIVT Id pick one and leave the other 16k in your HYSA or money market fund. Of course, youd have to rebalance it, say one a month might be enough, so it stays within the target asset mix and you dont overexpose on one end or the other too much. Of course, theres plenty of mutual funds and ETFs that will do all of this for you at the cost of a bit of higher expense ratio. And if 2080 is too aggressive, then adjust as needed.

One thing Ive done is look up higher yield bonds on the secondary market that pay a coupon and are maturing soon. For example, I bought a 10year bond that paid a 6 coupon but the 10year was maturing like 4 months from when I bought it. That way I was getting a higher APR running somewhat less of a risk than locking up my money for 10years on a shaky bond. Its a more handson approach because you then need to roll that investment into something new, but thats actually what youre looking for in terms of liquidity.

Your own personal risk tolerance should be considered. However, as a rule of thumb, theres no real benefit to paying off any debt early when the rate is below 44.5, especially a mortgage. The tax adjusted expected return from most investments would be higher than the rate you are paying. Seems like you have a big enough fund that you could potentially do a rolling CD plan. Invest X every X months on a rolling basis. So if you take 12 of your fund and invest 1 every month into a CD, you can slightly higher rates than a HYSA. After a while, depending on the length of the CD, you will always have that 1 maturing monthly to maintain some liquidity. The drawback being if you have a bad emergency, you will have to wait for the next chunk to mature before you can use the funds, but if you do 6 month CDs, its not terrible, but it is essentially risk free since theyre FDIC insured and all. I do it with 6 months, so at least if I have an emergency that depletes my emergency fund, I can just use credit to pay for it temporarily until the CD matures to pay it off. With enough time, you could set it up for yearly, every 5 years, whatever, so that you always have some chunk maturing monthly.

replies.text: The internet is full of shady scam, just ignore it.
Its because A youre not using an adblocker and B because you visit content that has to do with investing so they sell your metadata to ad companies to target you

Yeah I would avoid any company that uses ads on Google, etc to gain investor traction. Companies with strong profiles would go with traditional channels to raise capital, and online ads are not a traditional channel. Usually a red flag and a sign to avoid

There is no substitute for doing your homework when investing, otherwise youre looking for trouble. Lots of these companies have an idea on paper and market it to sound good, but there is little depth. Key questions to ask 1 what kind of funding do they have already have they attracted serious investors 2 what are their sales, have they successfully commercialized their technologybusiness idea? 3 who is the management team, what experience and tenure do they bring to the business? Many if not most startups fail within a year or so. Good ideas do not equal commercial success. Id be very, very cautious with this type of investment. More scam and self enrichment than solid business ideas in most cases. One of my favorites is lithium mining. Yes, we need lithium for electronics and chips. But is some little startup going to change the way the global supply chain works? Hardly. Warren Buffett famously said if you dont understand it, dont invest in it. This approach has served me well.

Im not exposed to such ads but yes, this makes no sense. All scams one way or the other. Their business model is basically X amount of dollars for AdWords for 23X amount of dollars in returns. Whatever in between to get there is most likely fairy dust.

A. Any startup spending money on ads for crowdfunding is an immediate pass for me. I just think its poor judgement in money usage. B. Startups on crowdfunding sites are a bit different but still extremely risky. Remember the best on paper startups will find funding from private investorsfirmsbanks. So these startups have something tangible missing for the big players to pass on them. Are their winners on these sites? Yes, Beyond Meat was on one of these sites prior to its IPO. But thats a definite outlier and should not be considered the norm.
Interest rates are high and its hard to get funded right now, so this is the desperation well see for a while.
Theyre scams. Ignore and move on. There are more than enough legit investment opportunities out there for you to exlore, before you need to venture down these shady alleys.

They are using a strategy where a lot of poor people try to emulate the rich. A ton of rich people do investments or something with startups, and clearly THIS advertisement is my ticket out of here! I just need to wire them thousands of dollars!!!

It would be helpful to know which companies you are talking about. If we have a company name we could look at he actual information about that company. Without that we are just guessing. .What I do see occationally on news site are stores about some stocks or investor issues. They often look like stores you would find in barrons or other buisness newsletters and may discuss a specific company. But if you slick on it you often find after reading most of it you have to click to get the rest of the story. And often that is behind a pay wall. that are actually add from companies that offer investing serviees. I have never seen an add for a company ASKING for investors.
Could you share some what you saw? Ive never seen ads like these.

The stuff youre describing is the digital version of a used car salesman with a mustache and aviator glasses who vaguely smells like wet pine needles and just a hint of mayonnaise, even though were 2 hours past the most recent meal time. Scams are scams, you just have to learn how to spot them. General rule if it disappears when you install an adblocker, its a scam.

Ive worked in venture capital and capital markets for the past 10 years. You will be surprised how many great companies Im talking fast topline growth 10M with promising catalysts struggle to raise capital. I dont think its fair to penalize companies that turn to digital marketing to get their story out. Amazon was first a small penny stock company that had massive debts and on the verge of bankruptcy. Of course, 90 of startups will fail, this is just the game. But were in a digital age, and theres a lot of startups raising capital that are competing for attention. Id personally be impressed with a startup that has impressive advertising and can get their story across in a convincing way and back it up with credible data validation, which would show me theyre a sophisticated group of minds that understand how to sell. Remember, youre betting on the scrappy founders, not the product or startup itself.
I would never respond to a request for an investment . The chance it is a scam is enormous. Even if legit the chance of seeing your money again is virtually zero.
More than likely scam. Like the law firms advertising on TV, dont trust it! Do you research.
Ublock origin and Firefox is a must.

replies.text: historical data has shown that dividend paying stocks tended to outperform their non dividend paying counterparts. If dividends dont inherently add value, why is this the case? Life is not just about numbers. And the differences between dividend payments and stock buybacks involve a great deal more than math. Dividends are usually distributed in a systematic way, and cutting dividend payments is seen as a very bad sign. So, a dividend is in effect a statement by management that they believe the company can perform and continue to deliver into the future. Boeing is a case study. Prior to 1998 investment in new aircraft programs and the companys reputation was seen as a way to protect investors, and the dividend, well into the future. Post 1998 the Jack Welch school that came to control the company was focused on short term results and stock buybacks. The difference between Boeing today and what is called in the industry legacy Boeing is stark.

This is well documented but too often ignores the behavioral story. You touch on the misconceptions in your final paragraph. But perhaps they know themselves. By that I mean there are people for whom dividends have psychological benefits, meaning the ability to hold equity at all is improved by knowing the dividends are coming in.
In certain countries like Australia dividends have special treatment from a tax perspective also, which makes it an attractive component of total return.

What about people who are in distribution. Doesnt having some focus not total focus on quality stocks that are divided players help with cash flow during periods where sequence of return risk would be detrimental

Its a nice thought experiment, but youre taking it too far in your conclusions. Assumptions like management will always spend money in good faith to maximize earnings are useful if you want to make a world that is spreadsheetcompatible, but massively off the mark from the real world. In the real world management has incentives like getting the stock price to a certain number by a certain time to get a payout, future be damned. Creating unrealistic narratives about future earning to justify or increase PE ratios you know are excessive. Tech is a huge part of the SP500 and these problems are very common in tech. Around the dotcom crash this all got so bad that nobody could give out any dividends at all, for fear of demonstrating that they dont have endless golden geese lined up that the money would be better spent on. These days theyve gotten a little better about this and your Apple, Microsoft, and Google at least pay out a nominal dividend of like 0.51. Investors regularly get their money pissed up the wall like this in tech, when they would have been much better off just receiving it as a dividend than having tens of billions wasted on the metaverse with promises that all life would revolve around this concept in a few years, only to have them say actually never mind its all fake after a few years of stock options vesting at high valuations. Of course, were in the middle of a similar bubble with AI, so this all seems quaint now, but trust me, in a few years there will be a lot of people saying I wish they had just given me the money. So yeah, I like a small dividend, just to maintain a culture that this is my money they are playing with, and if they dont have a good use for it then Ill take it. However, dividends themselves are an irrelevant criterion for investment selection. thats not what Modigliani and Miller claimed. Their research has been consistently distorted and misrepresented over the years. Note that MM didnt say that dividends were irrelevant they said, under their extremely narrow conditions, that dividend payout ratios should be irrelevant to the overall value of the firm. That is a specific finance claim, not a generalized disregard for dividend payments. It is not what MM said its what people now think they said. Theres a big difference. Empirical evidence, such as the drop in stock prices on the exdividend date, supports this theory. All opening bids and offers are adjusted down by the amount of the dividend and any shareholders at the open are entitled to the dividend.

The Dividend Irrelevance Theory, proposed by Modigliani and Miller MM in 1961, asserts that dividend policy has no impact on a firms value or cost of capital in a frictionless market. Everything you say is true but investing is a personal situation driven game. During your accumulation phase you would be wrong to have any allocation other than a diversified portfolio that is spread between growth and value with some adjustment for whether we are in a Value or a Growth phase in the market. In the Early Accumulation phase you should be heavily invested in equities as you dont much care about down cycles as you have little money at risk. In the late accumulation phase you start to build in a strategy for up and down markets as you now have some principal to protect. In the Preretirement stage you start to worry more about beta and less about alpha particularly if you have done a good job of accumulation. In Retirement your goals are preservation and income, so less beta is more important than excess alpha unless you are late to the party. Assuming you have hit your goals, then joining rdividend and forgetting a growth allocation makes total sense. In that stage assuming a good number, you can use the dividends and leave the kids the equities at whatever value they may have when you are gone. Id actually argue that all else equal, dividends are actually a structural headwind to returns. As you point out, dividends are just a mandatory liquidation of a portion of the market cap of the company. Any investor who owns the stock via a basket e.g. an index fund investor who reinvests dividends is effectively going short the stock vs long the other stocks in the basket and actually reinvesting an even smaller portion than they would have otherwise because the dividend reduces the companys weight in the index. Extending the work of Koijen et al, this imbalanced flow should have a lasting price impact on the stock relative to the other constituents in excess of the fundamental change in the value of the companys assets

You would be knowledgable on a subject then, perhaps you can answer it. My understanding is, your actual numerical value of debt is essentially irrelevant provided you have the cashflow to make a lender comfortable. Is this ballpark accurate?

Correct. The most common way a lender will look at the quantum of debt they are willing to extend is a multiple on cash flow. So if you generate 100m in cash flow a year, a lender will most likely be willing to extend 300 400m or 3 to 4x cash flow. The primary reason being is a company will trade at some much higher multiple say 7 to 20 times depending on business so if youre only lent 3 to 4, you are safely inside a potential EV of the company. Secondarily, the lender wants to ensure you generate enough cash flow to cover the interest expense of the debt. There are other underwriting metholdogies though, multiple on recurring revenue or pure asset based lending against liquidation value of assets are two other common ones

Up until 2 years ago all employer match had to be on a pretax basis, even if the employee contribution was Roth. The new law SECURE 2.0 allows employer match to be Roth. However, the IRS hasnt issued guidance on the particulars, so I dont believe a single employer has actually adopted it yet. Having said all that, the best thing to do is just call the firm who manages your 401k. Theyre the only one who can give you 100 confirmation of your plans setup.
401k match is always traditional pretax
If you stay in the state tax free place in retirement then it doesnt matter really. But yes typically matches are always pretax.

There is also another SECURE 2.0 wrinkle it involves catchup contributions to 401Ks if you are over 50 an extra 7500 you can contribute for high income earners above 145,000. The IRS had mandated that these now have to be done as a Roth 401 contribution and therefore taxed in the year it is done. But most companies dont have a mechanism setup to do this yet, so the IRS delayed implementation until after 2025. So SECURE 2.0 affected 401K matching contributions as well as catchup contributions.

All correct, I just wanted to add that OP would have also likely had to select the Roth option for matching, if Walmart offers it. I doubt that matching would only be offered as Roth. If both are offered, Roth is unlikely to be the default option. OP would have to read their plan documents to be sure. A lot of HR and benefits people are ill informed, and the documents are the definitive source. And just for OPs awareness, the 401k custodian sometimes buries the balance information on the tax treatment of different contribution buckets. But rest assured that they are required to keep track of that information for you. If you dig enough on their website, its there somewhere.

I prefer to keep my emergency fund in short term treasury etfs... USFR and SGOV are two popular ones. They only hold 03 month treasuries and roll them on a seven day basis, so there is functionally no interest rate risk... Why these and not hysa? When you put deposits into a hysa, a bank uses those deposit to buy treasuries, and then collect the interest from the treasuries and pay out a slightly lower interest rate to their customers, making a spread the difference between what they receive and pay is profit... bank interest is also taxable at both the federal and state level... buying a short term treasury etf provides easy liquidity one business day, has a higher yield than HYSAs, and the monthly dividends are not taxable at the state level. Its not going to make a huge difference, but why not cut out the middleman and be more tax efficient with your cash equivalents?

Emergency fund is commonly used in reference to money designated for life emergencies. Investable cash, kept as cash, is usually referred to as a cash position or similar language in order to express that its separate from the emergency fund. Mathematically, cash positions are less effective than being fully invested, when the specific goal is maximizing returns. Time in the market beats timing the market is a popular mantra relating to that. However, some strategies use cash or uncorrelated assets alongside equities in order to rebalance or otherwise store gains or prepare for quick deployment of capital as opportunities arise. Personally, Im fully invested at all times. My taxable account is entirely buy and hold, broad market index funds. My 401k is in a target date fund. My IRA is where I use more active strategy. I hold 40 SSO 2x daily SP 500 leveraged ETF at all times, with the other 60 defaulting to VOO. When great swing trade opportunities pop up, or as allocation drift occurs, I move capital from the VOO side. This keeps me at 100 or more exposure to the SP 500 at all times, while allowing me a mechanism to also address opportunity. Since the account is tax advantaged, there is no tax drag.

That is not an easy to answer question... a lot of the advantage is dependent on which state you reside in.. if you are in FL or TX, then the difference will only be the difference in interest, so about 0.5... but if you live in CA or NJ, then the savings on state tax may be 10 of the gross interest income.. For 100k, if in a no income tax state, your looking at about an extra 500600 a year compared to HYSA, if you live in CA, NJ, etc, then the tax savings could be an additional 500600 a year, so an extra 10001200 a year. Not likely to move the needle, but its an extra 1000 to click buy in a brokerage instead of transfer between checking and savings, at the cost of delaying access of those funds by one business day.

Identical liquidity to any other etf or stock... sell during open market and funds settle next trading day and can be transferred out... so if you discover you need cash on friday after market close, funds wouldnt be transferred out until tuesday sold monday, settle Tuesday, transfer tuesday. That is the worst case scenario, aside from holidays that leave the market closed.

Its not a straight forward process... there are many methods for manufactured spending on credit cards.. the easiest and most expensive is plastiq... will cost 2.9 to use... but if you open up a citi double cash card, for example... it will come with 15 months 0 apr, a 200sign up bonus, and 2 cash back.. if you get a 20k limit, you can throw 18k on it, will cost 18,522 with fees, but then you will earn 370.44 in cash back on the 18522, plus the 200 sign up bonus, or 570.44, more than the 522 in fees, and then you have 18k you can use to buy bonds yielding 5. There are more lucrative ways to use credit cards to buy cash equivalents, but they get to be more complex gift card shenanigans... I found I can overpay my HoA with a credit card and they will mail a check back for the refund... things like that... the goal is to find a way to buy cash equivalents that can be converted back into cash with less than 2 slippage to transaction cost... it can be done, new methods pop up and get patched because of abuse.

I see this as another equally good option.. money market accounts have blended holdings paying depositors interest. This is not really a criticism or a particularly good reason to avoid them. However, I prefer purity in my holdings so I can mentally account for them easier. That is a personal preference that should not sway you away from using SPAXX.

Remarkable is a subjective term. I also have not explained everything I am doing. In addition to my emergency fund of 50k75k, I also keep a few 0 APR credit cards close to maxed out and the proceeds in the same fund, to the tune of another 75k. I wouldnt call the difference remarkable, but significant enough for me to bother with a few extra mouse clicks. I think old fashioned community banking is an interesting field and a business model I enjoy. While no one will give me deposits for me to make spreads on, I can synthetically acheive the same thing with 0 apr intro offers with credit cards.. this lead me to optimize for the spread income and taxes and this is where I landed that balanced the risk, taxation, and interest to my liking.

I am sure there are similar funds that are eurodenominated... but I dont know them off the top of my head. For no imterest rate risk, you need short term maturities... though, at least in the US, we are cutting rates, so some long term bond funds could be potentially attractive, but I wouldnt recommend for a true emergency fund.

I dont suggest most people do what I am doing. Credit and credit cards are a tool. If you are young and still establishing yourself, its best to avoid any shenanigans and focus on your career.. once you are established and buy your forever home and just finishing buying a new car and have enough in savings and investments to buy a new car outright if you really needed to... thats when its time to ask if there are other ways to use your tools than how they were originally intended.. until then, play it straight and avoid trouble. Many people also have trouble with credit and self control in the same way alcoholics have trouble with alcohol, so I generally dont recommend people use credit cards to begin with unless they are naturally frugal. That said, I think you drastically overestimate the long term effect of opening multiple credit cards. See the wiki at rchurning for more information... but having opened and closed over 70 credit cards over the last 15 years, my wifes credit score is above 800, and my credit score with 5 maxed out credit cards and another dozen with no balance is still above 740... again, this happens once you have a long history of responsible credit use across dozens of different credit accounts among different loan types... if your 22 and have only ever had 2 credit cards and a student loan, opening a bunch of them will crash your score... for 612 months unless you carry a balance. After 612 months, if you used them responsibly and didnt carry a bunch of debt, you will find your credit score is higher than it was when you opened them. Best of luck to you!

If your goal is to beat market return as it appears, I would recommend that every few years you do the math for yourself and compare your return against the indexes like VOO, VT, VTI. Most retail investors that pick their own stocks do not, and it is often a game of beating it one year and missing the next. how did the portfolio do against the sp last yr? this yr to date? imho, 19 companies across numerous ndustries are too excessive.

I personally dont think its possible to do proper research on that many companies. For example, with Amazon alone, they have so many divisions aside from retail and AWS. Can you really stay updated on the antitrust lawsuits against it? What about their healthcare ventures? Do you know their lead competitors in their pharmacy business or their plans to grow their virtual telehealth division? Of course, maybe you can convince yourself that the level of research and analysis youve done for each company is sufficient. But I think thatd be a tad bit naive. The amount of analysis is always going to be infinite, and unless you have your own bulletproof definition of what constitutes a good company, Id argue that you may as well just buy more index funds and save yourself the hours of research. Also a more general hot take...how do you know what strong management looks like? Or what a dominant market position looks like? Genuine question, because I am not fully convinced that those are meaningful metrics, although I may be wrong. All of the best companies have phenomenal talent in their Csuite that went to Harvard or Wharton. And they all have significant market capture. I just dont think those metrics should play a significant role in your investment decision. They seem handwavey to me.
They are all awesome companies. However, what matters just as much is your cost basis

replies.text: Then I suspect stocks not in those funds would be very undervalued and great opportunities.

If there were no buyers, then prices would drop until buyers came into the market. If there were no sellers, then prices would rise until sellers came into the market. Any imbalance with indexing would allow active sellers to come in and take advantage of bargains, until prices stabilized.
It would mean the three people who hadnt would control the market.
Inefficiencies would be revealed in the market and people would clamor to take advantage of them. Then the pendulum would swing back to individual stocks and managed portfolios.

There will come an equilibrium point where the marginal investor is equally well served between going passive, and paying someone to invest actively for them. If people keep going passive beyond that, then there will be more and more free lunches available for active investors to exploit, and as they get more obvious the fees which you would need to pay someone to do it would get lower, all tending back towards equilibrium. The fact that active investors continue to fail as a group to best passive, even before their fees are considered, indicates this is a long way off. Also bear in mind that price discovery is achieved by volume of trades, not assets under management. 99 of assets held passively while the remaining 1 are traded around at high frequency discovers price just as well as 5050 with lower frequency. To the degree AUM have become more passive, it is massively offset by high frequency algorithmic trading of the remainder. These narratives about passive bubbles are just lies spread by wall street to scare people into paying more for worse returns. They understand the above even better than I do.
These videos answer your question in detail

Indexes are not passive. Ultimately they are managed, just funds that track them dont have to be managed, they just have to replicate what changes the index makes. Which actually creates a problem for funds that physically replicate the index when there are major market events. It is why there are so many index funds that are not older than the 2008 meltdown.

If bar none every person with stocks refuses to sell them and other people want to put money in, THEN money still flowing into fund companies like Vanguard would only be able to acquire shares from companies who make them available and every company would start making shares available. Most companies are having stock prices near ATHs now and most companies are willing to issue new stock at ATHs. Companies that are lower than normal could hold out and then companies like Vanguard couldnt buy stock in any company without affecting the weighting of the funds. Those companies would likely cave so that index funds can continue to operate as normal. The price wouldnt have to change, because there would only be one issuer and no secondary market. All companies could continue to issue shares at the price the underlying was at when all investors stopped selling their shares. If the stocks at low valuations couldnt be pressured to issue new shares, index funds would just have to stop accepting new money. That would leave money in peoples 401ks or whatever which they could put in a Money Market or a Bond fund or something instead.
Id probably make a ton more money. Itll never happen. Ever.

My guesstimate is that thats already happened. Where do the pro ball players go to then..? To leveraged index plays, to playing on volatility, etc. And if the sums are large enough theyll make the index funds a lot less stable of an investment, on short term.

The only sellers would be people withdrawing from these index funds, and if they arent too many, there wont be shares to buy when the SIP monies start coming in each month. What would they do then? Index funds use an Authorized Participant system as middlemen to createdestroy shares. Google it. APs buy the securities of the index to create new shares as needed. There is no such thing as no shares available to buy.
We will find out soon enough.
All stocks would rise and fall from their initial valuations at the same rate, regardless of actual performance.
Market would tend more towards inefficiency than efficiency. Its a paradox. Indexers need stockpickers and vice versa.

if all investors shifted to lowcost index funds and abandoned speculative investing, markets could become less efficient, with weaker price discovery and corporate governance. Market volatility might decrease, but so would the potential for highrisk, highreward returns, and capital for small or innovative companies would become scarcer. Over time, this could lead to a less dynamic and innovative economy, despite greater stability for investors. However, in reality, such a scenario is unlikely, as different types of investors have varied risk tolerances, goals, and investment strategies, which helps maintain a balance in financial markets.

Im a real FA. There are so much better ways to invest with fees. Strategic SMA portfolios. A full wrap fee with individual ETFs they manage. If I may ask what firm are they at where they are pushing this? Sounds like a bad firm
Several million? American Funds? Big payday for that advisor if they can close the deal!

hot take if you cant quickly convince someone to avoid a high AUM managed fund like this they probably need to be paying someone to manage their money. make a small effort to introduce low cost index funds and if they dont bite it is not your problem.

So...could she do better, the answer is pretty clearly yes. Buy, just to be that guy... What does SHE need and want? Does she need something where she can just call her guy and they will handle getting her liquid cash from her investments? If shes not sophisticated, and doesnt want to trouble a family member or share that info with when she needs to make a sale not to mention that at this asset value her tax implications need addressed due to eventual MedicareMedicaid planning, she may be better served paying for services. That said also, would she consider sitting down with an independent fiduciary to get a 2nd opinion? NAPFA is the organization to start with. Some of them offer a middle ground of managed while still maintaining fiduciary status.
You can show them this. Proof that he is flat lying. 40 years outperformance.

Hold on. Is your MIL asking for your help? Then its really none of your business. Yes shes probably getting fleeced in fees, but you should only be saying that sort of stuff if shes asking for your advice.

Advisor can buy load waived A shares, advisor will make around 1 the first year and .25 after. GFA is a good fund, more diversified than the SP. She could do a lot worse but might want to diversify with other American Funds.

Edward Jones often pushes American Funds. Frontloaded crap. The family friend will make a mint in commission off of her, I suppose. Any outperformance will be swamped by the fees and the expense ratio.

Im seeing 0.63 expense ratio for AGTHX, which seems egregiously high, such that I would look no further into it, definitively discarding this option. If she cant be made to understand how bad this expense ratio is, Im not sure what hope there is.

I mean, isnt the historical performance available to compare??? Of course you have to compare on a net of fee basis. A Quick Look on Yahoo finance shows SPY outperforms over 3 and 5 years. There may be some recency bias in her friends argument.

The privately held LA based company Capital Group owns American Funds. So there are fees and profit motives for sure, and Capital Group usually caters to institutional buyers. Over the last 10 years the AGTHX fund returned about 70, but the SPY would have returned 190. In the early days of AGTHX, they were nimble and always outperformed the SP, but now they have about 150 billion in assets, so best case for them is to match the SP the same thing happened to the Magellan fund years ago. In other words, AGTHX is so big diverse, they are essentially the SP. As for me, 1 i like ETFs because of the same day liquidity, 2 i like to spread the money around at least 5 to 10 funds there are lots of youtube videos that speak to a 5 fund strategy, or a 9 fund strategy etc etc, 3 i might do a mutual fund if i like the sector. in my view the advice to toss it all into the AGTHX is not prudent. Maybe to save face, she allocates something like 5 to the fund and seeks lower cost options from Vanguard or cost effective ETFs.

A 0.63 expense ratio for what, exactly? That fund is hella expensive for being the equivalent of 87.2 VOO, 10 VXUS and some money in a money market fund in to make it a pseudo balanced fund, to use the term loosely.
If this guy is a friend, I would hate to see one of her enemies! This guy sounds worse than a used car salesman!

Get a second or even third opinion on how to best use the funds in her situation by making an appointment with a financial consultant. They will do a questionnaire for suitability, including risk tolerance. Lots of people like Schwab, Fidelity and Vanguard. Funny business will less likely be tolerated at bigger places, who have much to lose compared to a freelancer advisor.

The advisor is either delusional or lying about AGTHX consistently beating the SP500 after fees. Either way would disqualify them from advising me. They are not a friend. They are grifting sales slime. Is there going to be an Assets Under Management fee on the account. 11.5 is typical. 1 on 3M would be 30,000 a year. Thats a lot to pay to grifting sales slime. If MIL doesnt know how to manage several mil they may need an advisor, but not this one. Vanguard PAS at 0.3 AUM would probably take care of it. For several mil the major brokers will provide you a personal advisorrep for no or low cost. Be careful about getting in the middle of this and advising. Stock prices can easily have times, sometimes years, of declines. You could get irrationally blamed for them losing money.

Read prospectus for each fund and compare fees. Past performance is not an indicator of future returns. If she believes someone let her be. Time will tell. Especially if you have no personal interest in someone else finances and it wont affect you in anyway.

VFIAX is the highest performing fund currently. Ive made a lot of money with it over time. You can google best performing index funds 2024 and it will list them.

AGTHX is not an index fund so not really apples to apples comparison. There is nothing really wrong with American Funds actively managed funds. Are they the best funds if you had a choice, no. There are actively managed funds that do beat the index funds with lower fee from other fund families. American Funds are popular with investment advisors because it is a fund family they can become affiliated with to resell. They do have some solid offerings. My wifes employer switched to them a few years ago, which is a massive improvement over their previous 401k custodian. Depending on your risk tolerance and objectives index funds are not the end all of investments.

I rolled over an old IRA that was completely made up of three different American Funds. The first thing I did was to sell and most all shares and buy SCHX. Im doing much better now and couldnt wait to get rid of the leeches that were sucking me dry for too many years.

It is actually in recent months AGTHX is doing better than SWPPX 0.02 not over longer time. It comprises of less 316 companies. American funds tend to be more pricy. But every feels different with a family friend involved. No VOO does not have the lowest expense. There are two others charge less.

They have outperformed the SP500. The only problem is you have to go back 42 years and let it ride. I did a back test from 2007 till 2017, AGTHX had a 53 shortfall against VOO. Back test it 1,3,5, and 10 years.
Is he with Edward jones? American funds is their go to. Thats how you get paid
Never let family friends act as financial advisers, and do not put all eggs in one basket. Diversification and low costs are key criteria.
VOOG is basically identical to QQQ performance wise at a cheaper expense ratio.

Im late to the post but here goes. I had a financial advisor once. He was incredibly helpful in the strategy phase. Figuring out how to structure my money around short, medium, and long term goals. I paid 1000 for that service which resulted in around 8 hours of sessions. I really appreciated him for that. Of course, I took the next step and used him for investments. All American funds. All at a 1 expense, which underperformed because they were all the same stocks as the cheap index funds which charged .05 expense ratios. He was getting paid for the American funds and I can understand that. But telling someone to invest in a SP500 fund is not exactly skilled financial advice. After a year I told him thanks and see you later and moved everything into VOO.
Pretty sure it has a front load fee. To many funds Without a load, to pay a load. I would say get a second opinion. Take your time no rush.

Most people would disagree with me, but putting ALL of your money in an actively managed large cap growth fund is not a good way to diversify a portfolio. Especially when large cap growth is trading at multiples that havent been seen since 2000. This fund had a drawdown of 65.31 in the early 2000s. And I am sure this same advisor will be trying to put you in something else later on, possibly changing to another fund family so you will have to pay another 5.75 load.
QQQM is a lower fee, lower volume twin to QQQ. Unless you are trading high volume its a better deal like VOO vs SPY.

The American fun familys been around since the 1930s theres nothing wrong with them when I was a child I received prior to what was calling augment account but an investment that was for my benefit later in life for my grandfather who put some money in investment Company of America which is under the umbrella the American funds. Over 18 years it turned into quite a bit of money.. would you need to understand is most stock brokers money managers recommend it because its a load fund with a five and a quarter up front fee which is pretty heavy relative to everything else nowadays and even if you sign whats called rights of accumulation where you commit to investing a certain amount to lower your breakpoint of your upfront fees its still a lot.. you can go to vanguard and get an SP index fund or one of the vanguard longterm growth funds and their returns are going to be relatively similar because theyre going to only seen type of companies theres a great deal of overlap you may have more coke in one and more Pepsi in another and more McDonalds and one more Walmart in another but youre going to have a great deal of overlap.. would you have to understand is if youre going to an investment broker or a cfp youre going there for a reason because you need advice and if you go there and you choose not to use them thats fine but if you go there and you keep picking their brain but you never invest with them its going to be a very short conversation at some point in time because thats what used to happen to me a long time ago. I meet with clients multiple times they come to the office understand my investment approach what Im looking for you understand what their financial needs are there Risk tolerances you qualify them you get everything done and you disclosed to them like this is what we would invest in ABCD this is the approach and they basically take your information and leave and go elsewhere is where they do it themselves.. thats the risk of the business but a lot of times they would come back later and go well this didnt work out well what didnt work out will this particular investment well we didnt do anything together so why are you asking me what the problem is because I had no knowledge that you were taking our conversation elsewhere is an investing.. I have friends this day that are cfps that are very good theyre honest they follow whats called The prudent mans rule they put the customer first the company second and there needs dont even get factored in the equation.. and within the industry theres a lot of slime balls.. you can have all of your needs taken care of from a longterm investment standpoint from vanguard or fidelity or similar the whole idea of putting it into a mutual fund is its actively managed and as times change the percentage of investments in different companies change. Or you can just go into an index fund whatever the market does it does and my suggestion to you would be to consistently dollar cost average in every single month and dont look at the principal because when the market goes up and you invest you buy less when the market goes down you buy more shares and 20 30 years down the road when it comes time for you to cash out youre going to have a lot of money. I hope the sheds a little bit of insight if you have any questions please feel free to ask

Its perfectly reasonable for someone to hire a financial advisor and pay him. However, people should hire feebased planners. They will charge you for their time like a lawyer and provide more objective advice. A commissionbased advisor will steer you towards more expensive, commissionbased products. Consider, a feebased advisor might charge a few thousand dollars up front for a plan. After that you spend a few hundred dollars each year for a checkup. The commission planner doesnt charge the investor, but puts himher into high fee products. On 2 million, this fund actually waives the frontend load. However, it still charges an annual 12b1 fee of 0.24, about 4800, every year. This money goes to the selling broker.
Agreed. Lots of armchair experts here. Some folks need guidance, and that costs money. Better to pay a fee than mismanage millions. Its not always as simple as just index and chill.

RealWorld Example Many companies offer mutual funds with varying loads to meet the investing style of any investor. American Funds Growth Fund of America AGTHX is an example of a mutual fund that carries a frontend load. To illustrate how the load works lets say an investor invests 10,000 in the AGTHX fund. They will pay a frontend load of 5.75, or 575. The remaining 9,425 is used to purchase shares of the mutual fund at the current share net asset value NAV price.3 Capital Group. The Growth Fund of America Summary Prospectus Pages 12. My understanding of mutual fund front load expense is perfectly accurate. My awareness of American Funds fee waiver schedule was lacking.

content.text: Opinions on American Funds? Better than SPY and QQQ?

replies.text: Investing gets easier and for most people more profitable when they stop worrying about such things. Owning the total market is cheaper than ever in fee terms and remains the best option in almost all circumstances.

Yes. People want to be confident they are making the smartest decision with their money, and when index funds have been touted as the smartest investment option for years then you will hear a lot of people suggesting index etfs. There are many bullish signals and projections for equitiesVOO and no one knows how high they can go, but also no one knows what will happen. There are individual sectors and companies trading at lower valuations. But US equities are expensive, its wishful thinking to deny the risk of VOO over the midterm. The market is unpredictable now and always

For several months now, I have been guilty of looking at things going on in the macroeconomic environment, and been certain that we are long overdue for a correction. 21 over 9 months 10 over 6 months 8.75 over 3 months. classic example of why timing the market doesnt work. markets are almost always at all time highs, youll be constantly thinking its over valued by a single metric. i am guessing you are not a financial professional, and have no education in macro economics or statistics. because of this, just invest, and forget about it.

Markets have a good way of telling you you dont think it can happen, but it can throughout history with double digit rates, oil shocks, currency devaluations and so on, things never imagined could happen because it never did. With todays money printing there is no reason the SP500 cant go to 50 pe. Ray Dalio thinks so too. Challenge your backwards facing beliefs.

Interesting how all 3 of your only 3 times are within the past 20 years in other words, it never happened in the first 70, then happened 3 times in the next 20, and most recently about 5 years ago. PE of 30 isnt that crazy. People have been saying the markets overpriced for my whole adult life, although Im only 38, Ive at least lived through 2008 and Covid, enough to know what the world looks like when everyone thinks its ending. And all I really see is everyone wishes theyd gotten in earlier and invested more aggressively. Now seems like a pretty average time to me. People arent talking crazy in either direction. Its a pretty normal maybe this, maybe that kind of time. Based on the overall sentiment I expect now will prove to be an average time to enter the market. The regrets are from people who tried to time the market. The one valid proven strategy throughout history is to invest as much as you can as early as you can. Focus on earning more money so that you can invest more and invest as much as you can now.
It is overpriced compared to what it used to be, but it may not be overpriced compared to what it will be. Clear as mud?
The market is indeed severely overpriced.

The real question is where is the most attractive place to invest at any given time, and the answer is virtually never cash. Certainly, given the amount of stimulus pumped into the economy over the past few years, the current situation for US equities, and particularly the SP 500, is short on precedent. However, Mega Cap US equities are only one of many asset classes even European equities have much lower PE ratios, not to mention those dirty words fixed income. I personally dont expect the SPs dominance in returns to last forever nothing does. Ive still got a lot invested in it, but have also taken some profits and shifted money into assets with more attractive valuations.
Possibly, but theres always risks involved.
More money has been lost trying to plan for corrections than the actual corrections Peter Lynch
Didnt we just have a correction? For those waiting for one to get in
Yes
Where did you get the PE? Im seeing a forward PE of 23 for SPY
J
Yet another timing the market post.

I wouldnt say the market is in bubble territory. Not even close. Sure, some companies are overvalued. Theres almost always instances of that. But if you look past the perpetual overvaluation of big tech over the last handful of years, most companies are pretty fairly priced. Even still, these companies have been delivering. Its not like theyre propped up for no reason. The Dot Com bubble was mainly due to companies with basically no revenueprospects exploded in value. Only to tumble when people realized it was a house of stinky cards with nothing to show for it. And valuations got insane to like 5065 PEs. Were at about 2530 currently. Although smaller caps and mid caps is more around 20ish. The financial crisis was mainly due to horrendous lending practices and way too much bogus debts that imploded. Causing the market to tumble and bankscompanies on the brink of collapse. Were no where near this. Especially since our regulations are more full proof and banks stress test these potential scenarios much better. Despite all time highs across the board the economy has been quite strong and warrants this. Sure, were a bit over valued. But Id still invest like usual. Id just be wary of high flyers. Maybe be more selective and invest in strong companies with more sensible valuations. I personally love SCHD ETF and its valuation is only at like a 16 maybe 17 PE currently. Hell, DCAing into SPYVOO is still perfectly fine. Or any other major indexfund. Its all about the long term.

I feel the concentration and overvaluation at the very top end is a considerable risk. Current CAPE ratio of 42 indicates well be lucky to see 05 return over the next 15 years. I dont think were in bubble territory yet, not do I think were certain to get a major crash and the market can certainly go higher in the short term, but there isnt really anywhere for PE ratios to go other than down in the long term, which makes future strong returns unlikely
Depends on who you ask. Some say yes. Some say there is still room to grow.
Yes. The market is severely overpriced.

Speculating here Something feels very off. Massive inflation which still isnt at the 2 target, yet we are cutting rates. Job number being revised down by 800,000. Gold keeps breaking into record highs. Stock market at all time highs. To me it feels like the data is lying and the economy is about to pop but I thought that last year and missed out on a lot of gains. So who knows
all of what you mention is priced in by the market. what isnt priced in is some macroeconomic event the rocks the world and markets such as a terrorist attack.

YES, however America has never printed AKA loaned Tens of trillions of dollars in a few years like they have been doing, so we are probably going to have a super bubble with the market crashing up and then falling like an elevator with a depression style downcycle. Not even the best of the best economists know what is going to happen here, because America has never been here. Especially our income to debt National ratio.

I would think a better question is why do you think the market is overpriced as opposed to just being at a high price? Its very easy to point at a historical high before a crash and say well there was clearly a dotcom bubble here and a subprime mortgage catastrophe there but the market being at a high price only means theres a tall ledge to fall off of, it doesnt mean anything is going to push. If you think there will be a correction, why? This isnt me doubting your claim, but that if youre willing to put money on it you should have a good reason for your own benefit and certainty.
Who cares? Dollar cost average a 500 fund and chill.

Yes black swans can tank the market and the market can obviously be irrational as it likes to be from time to time, but everything tracks global liquidity full stop. And the current Global liquidity cycle is just now starting to ramp up. So prices are going a lot higher from here. The FED is way too high on interest rates still so those will be coming down a lot more by the end of next year. They also have to refinance trillions in debt and nobody wants to do that at a high interest rate. The money printer will be turned on in earnest soon enough. This is also an election year, they will juice the markets as much as needed to give the incumbent the edge. Simple thing to do is to remember we are in a Perpetual global debt cycle. This newly established fouryear cycle of raising rates, tightening, then cutting rates and pumping liquidity has been on loop since 2008. We are nowhere near the end of the party for this Mini cycle. Buy and Hold as normal or if you want to trade buy in the beginning of the cycle, sell towards the end of the cycle. Me personally I dont trade it too much, I just buy when things are on sale. And then take some profit off the table when it smells toppish.

If you adjust for inflation, markets are not anywhere near all time highs over 50 of the time. After some crashes, the market will hang out substantially below the high for decades. The 1929 peak was not reached again until 1959. The 1968 peak was not reached again until 1993. The 2000 peak was not reached again until 2015. For people ready to spend some or all of their money in the next decade, I dont think it would be foolish to transition some of their stocks into bonds until youre ready to spend. I think it is overpriced for several reasons, but primarily because history would tell us when price to earnings reaches this point, it is overpriced. I like to think that historical precedents mean something. But even if we get rid of what has happened in the past when we reach this PE I think a simple eye test, or logic test, tells you we are overpriced. If we took every company in the SP and assumed they had exactly 0 expenses. No labor costs. No cost of goods sold. No taxes. No rent. No payments on debt. No advertising exepnses literally nothing. And then those companies began taking every single penny of revenue, and distributed it to the holders of their stock. It would take 30 years, on average, for those investors to get their money back. If my mother could ask to to purchase a share of her company, with the aforementioned payment timeline, I would tell her to drink another Pepsi. Yet that is the reality aggregate average reality for the 500 largest companies in America.

Thats not what it concludes by any stretch of the imagination. The hypothetical humans with better hypothetical timing made more hypothetical money, and this is quantified explicitly in graph form halfway down the page. As usual, the argument isnt that market timing doesnt work. Buying low and selling high is a 100 flawless method to get a better profit. The problem is that you dont know when the bottom is and when the top is. Thats always the problem. Yes it works, but you and 85 of hedge fund managers cant do it. So what the article actually proves is that even if you have the worst timing ever, that still beats no action. This means that if you feel like trying to time the market, go for it, it makes very little difference even if you get it as mathematically dead wrong as possible. Time it if you want to, dont time it if you dont want to, but what these examples show is that arguing about whether or not to time it is extremely pointless. The difference between the Perfect hypothetical and the Rotten hypothetical is near negligable long term, the Linger example is the only actual loser the article presents.

What a ridiculous analysis. In the world of reality you adjust prices for equities to the same point in time if you want to compare them. All assets, including bonds and equities, need to be adjusted for inflation. Just because you dont know how much youre going to be able to sell your equities for in the future doesnt mean you dont need to adjust your returns on the stocks for inflation. There was a decade starting in the 70s where inflation averaged nearly 10yr. If equities had increased by 5 per year over the same period, you couldnt logically say equities are at an all time high, because they are actually worth less. You get more dollars but you can buy less total goods. To be totally accurate you should include dividends but its hard to find an SP500TR chart adjusted for inflation and Im too lazy to adjust the nominal chart. So like I said, I think it would be reasonable to sell stocks and purchase bonds if you are planning to spend the money in the next few years because the stock market could tank and not recover for decades. If you purchase TIPS, it will at least cover inflation, essentially locking in your gains todate with way less risk. It is patently insane to not adjust the performance of your equities for inflation.

Ive grown up running businesses with my parents, and have run several as an adult. If you were a friend coming to me with this question, here are a few things Id offer for you to consider and some are probably repeated from others in this thread. 1. If theres no urgency, take your time. Conversations with your spouse assuming its a good longterm relationship will perhaps be the most valuable and important part of the process. How does it impact your family life, goals, travel, etc.? Go out to dinner and kick around scenarios. 2. Write out the worstcase scenarios. What would you do if the business went bellyup? Sometimes its not as bad as you think. What would your exit plan or fixit plan be if the business started bleeding cash or losing customers? Again, another great conversation with your spouse. 3. Take time digging into the financials. If the owner gets defensive or protective, then thats a red flag. They should want to be transparent. 4. How much could you scale the company and how long would it take. For instance, Im hoping to double my business income and profit in the next 1218 months. If the company can only scale to a certain level, then Id figure that into my decision. Also, is it easy to scale without a lot of cash? Create a plan to scale the business and perhaps talk with the owner to get his thoughts. 5. Is your market easily disrupted, or does your business have a good moat protecting it? 6. Think through ways of lowering your risk. 125K might feel big, but acquiring a profitable company is not a huge investment assuming its truly profitable and growing. The bigger risks are the business risks, but they also have the biggest upside. Your investment might grow and could easily be replaced by your companys IRA over the next couple of years, back to lowering your risk. If youre uncomfortable investing the entire 125, you could work out a way to lower the sales price to 1 million or 750K, and do a profit share or something similar with the owner. Im not saying thats what you want to do, but its an option. It has its downsides. But for the owner, it could be a way for him to save on capital gains depending on how its structured. 7. Can you hire and fire? Its a small company, and it sounds like youll be the one doing thisor ultimately will need to make the call. Ive seen too many good small businesses languish because they drag things out. Either then dont hire to scale, or they allow toxic people to kill morale and productivity. If you cant do this, dont buy a business. 8. Get a mentor or coach from your industry. 9. Get an accountant and payroll person you LOVE LOVE LOVE working with and who is timely. This is one area where you want someone who is incredibly timely and topnotch competent. I hope that all helps. My final thought is that being a business owner, especially when its healthy, can be an amazing experience and really rewarding. Ive been doing it for over 35 years and done right, can give you a lot of freedom and the ability to provide great jobs to people you enjoy working with.

Private companies typically transact at five to 7 times trailing earnings, Public companies usually transact at 15 to 17 times, trailing 12 month earnings because they have the liquidity of being traded in a public market., please dont overpay for the company and ask your boss to see the last five years of financials and you need to look at cash flow, balance sheet, total revenue, all the expenses and see if it all jives with your experience having worked there. But since youve worked there and you know the company well, this could be the best investment opportunity of your lifetime. And I wouldnt pass it up just based on your fear of biting off more than you can chew, Especially if you can get financing for the bulk of the purchase. Then, after five to seven years, you basically own the business free and clear. And its all gravy for the next 20 years, until you retire. You are going to be working a job for the rest of your life, like most people. You may as well work for yourself. giving you more control And typically higher. earnings.

Do you exactly know what kind of work comes with owing a small company? I dont know about the US in special, but in general, most people seem to underestimate what someone owning such a company does, in addition to the actual business of the company, to keep in running. From marketing to finding employees, training, handling the staff and dealing with problematic customers, adapting to changing laws, accounting and taxes ... Also, think about the following You want to put the money for retirement into low risk investments. But youre willing to put 100 percent of savings and, in addition, a large amount of credit, into one single company that will probably go bankrupt once you have a serious medical problem. How did you calculate if the company is actually worth the amount that they ask for? Because some people forget that, what the investment on the company has to produce in earnings, you should not confuse with the salary one gets from working for the company, especially if you take into account the additional responsibilities if you own it and be CEO. If youre really that good in what youre doing, it could turn out to be a good alternative to start a small company yourself in a few years, investing only a portion without a big bank loan. Youre saving quickly these last few years, and if you switch, at least for a certain percentage, to stock market ETFs, the risk you want to take with a company and the risk you want to take with the rest, would align more and produce probably more the results youre looking for in life.

A market index fund investment will, over the long haul, give you a return about the same as the growth of the stock market over the same period of time. The two most important things to be careful of 1 Make sure youre investing in a solid index fund with a good long track record with a brokerage firm that is also just as reliable. And 2 Dont panic andor sell when the stock market goes down or even way down. It always goes down sooner or later and it always goes back up sooner or later. A friend of mine and her husband lost almost their entire lifelong savings in 2008 when the stock market plunged. They panicked and sold their holdings at the bottom of the plunge, and then couldnt afford to buy back into the market when it went back up. The time I myself lost money was when I was very young and gave 500 to a friend who had just become a stockbroker. He lost my money within six months. Some people prefer real estate. Others like individual stocks in established, profitable companies that pay dividends. Im sure youll hear about many more investment types and possibilities. Just be sure to do a lot of research, and to keep your preferred risk level in mind. I believe Charles Schwab reputable offers a lot of online research even if you dont have an account with them.

replies.text: Has anyone here reached fire by taking their entire savings and investing it into a single stock? Im sure that some people did not even close to the number of people who lost much of their money and greatly delayed their retirement and worsened their quality of life by attempting that, but still. But Im not certain that this is entirely the right question. A better one would be how many people reached fire by taking a risky bet of this sort and then stayed there? I suspect that the number is much smaller, for much the same reason why most people who make money gambling lose their money gambling when risky behaviour gets rewarded that simply encourages further risky behaviour, and sooner or later ones luck runs out. Lets say your bet pays off nicely and you reach your FIRE number for all I know it could happen, and I hope for you that it does. How long will it be before you start feeling that whatever sum you have is not quite enough to satisfy you entirely and find some other promising stock you feel very confident about and try the same trick again? After all, in this scenario you already proved your skills...

I dont say this to be harsh, but you are gambling, not investing, and this is a terrible idea. You are gambling on a stock that is just a step above penny stocks, whose only price movement right now is being driven by meme investing. You might as well be betting on sports. I also caution you to be less confident in your perceived investing expertise and ability. I think you are falling into the trap of using investing language you dont actually understand and its giving you a false sense of security. Your post reads like a lot of finance self investor Twitter, which is filled with investing idioms that sound legitimate, but are built on a fundamental misunderstanding of finance and investing. The mere thought of investing your lifes savings into a single stock, let alone a meme stock, is so ludicrous that you really should be hiring a financial advisor again. You were incredibly lucky and you are playing with fire. Again, I am not trying to dunk on you, but you are taking incredibly unnecessary risks that you dont seem to fully understand.

Its hard to say without knowing what stock youre talking about. But buying after it went up 60 instead of selling is probably something I personally wouldnt do. Let alone going that much deeper into the position. Now it doesnt have to go down nearly as much for you to be in the hole. Ive been investing for a few years and consistently beating the market by a good margin for 2 years. I put a lot of money on one stock at a time, not all of my money though, never all of my money even when I have more conviction in a investment than Ive ever had. Because thats just overly risky for no good reason, anything could happen. When were talking about hundreds of thousands of dollars and more what becomes just as important as growth, if not more important, is capital preservation. Where I personally think youre going wrong is trying to get rich quick. The turtle always wins the race. A compounding 1 weekly can already get you rich rather quickly, without betting the whole house on one stock. Too much risk. I also tend to sell as soon as I see a noteworthy profit. I like to compare returns to a couple different baselines. On a single position Im in, which I only focus on one position at a time in my trading account long term port of etfs separately, I compare my returns to a bondmoney market fund. People hold bonds for a year to make 5 less now, if youve been holding a stock for a month and are up 5, youre making 5 in just a month instead of a year, in other words thats 12x the return of a bondmmf. If you can make that in a week, as stocks can certainly fluctuate enough to do, than thats 52x more than a bond will pay per year, and people happily take their 5 a year so if you dont take a 5 gain in a week its almost greedy imo. When you can take a modest compounding 2.55 gain per week thatll make you quite wealthy within a couple years time. Shooting for stars and not selling when its good enough to screenshot is how people get wrecked, Ive seen it happen many a time and it even happened to me in the beginning. The second baseline is an obvious one, the SP. I only compare that baseline with my overall portfolio performance.

replies.text: There is so much nuance here, and so many different types of bond funds. I assume youre talking about BND? A total bond index like BND would have a lot of corporate bonds in them, and corporate bonds are not the best diversifiers for stocks. The best bonds for that are treasury bonds. In late april we started getting economic data that indicated economic slowdown. Unemployment started rising, inflation cooling, etc and people started to flee to flight to safety assets. Every time we got bad news, the market tumbled and treaury bonds spiked upwards. Here is the data from May 1st to now. Look at how long treasury bonds EDV spike whenever the large cap index drops. BND slightly does this as well, since as a total bond index it holds some long treasuries and corpo bonds not many, but the rate sensitivity of BND is not very strong. Its a poorer diversifier. Ignore the cagr, its misleading due to the short time period In the long term, treasury bonds are negatively correlated to stocks, while corporate bonds are weakly correlated so theyre okay diversifiers but not great. The times that long bonds and stocks move up together is during bull runs where rates are steady and inflation is steady.

I mean interest rates will affect both bonds and equities because changes in interest rates will affect the Present value of both, both bonds and equities have future cash flows that get discounted to a present value so changes in the discount rate affects both of them. Meaning I have a bond that matures in 20 years and I will get a lump sum payment of 10k. What is it worth today? We know 10k is 20 years is not worth 10k today , I mean no one would buy it for 10k to get zero returnunless we are in some weird deflationary environment . So we do some PV calculation that discounts it and we need to come up with a discount rate What do we use for this rate? I mean we could just use the current 5 rate but no one believes rates will be 5 for the next 20 years. So again we do some estimation guess and maybe we use 4.5 so using this rate its worth about 4,145.00 but now lets say new information comes out , and we change our estimate to 3.5 now that raised the PV to like 4,975.00 Well we can basically do a similar calculation to value companies , we make more estimation like what their future cash flows will be, but their future cash flows are still discounted . If we estimate a company to make 10 million dollars in year 20 , well that 10 million in year 20 is not with 10 million today , it gets discounted in a very similar fashion

while the funds track bonds mostly Bond funds track the bonds they hold exactly It would seem that they would inversely track equities Why? but that doesnt seem to be the case Yeah sometimes bonds correlate to stocks and sometimes anticorrelate. On average they have around neutral correlation. It would seem that any bond fund would have a basket of bonds of varying maturity. Many do though some have a single maturity. it seems that with a change in rates the entire basket would reprice. Yet it does not seem to be the case over the short run. Bond prices and yields are mathematically related so a change in yields of bonds definitely reprices a basket of those bonds. But yields of long term bonds will often anticipate changes in money market rates before the central bank officially changes their targets. And look beyond the short term rate policy to longer run macro conditions. And lower quality bonds have a credit component which higher quality bonds dont.
Also, the reason youre not seeing what youre expecting in the short term with rate cuts is that theyve been priced in over the last 6 months.
Thank you for that information. I am largely in VBTLX and thus not a pure government bond market so I guess that explains the reason.
Looks like VBTLX is just the mutual fund version of BND. Its a total market bond index. I added it to the test, you can see theyre identical

VBTLX is 50 government bonds, 25 corporate, 22 securitized, 3 cash equivalents. The average duration is 6 yrs measure of interest rate sensitivity, while a fund like EDVs is 24 yrs. VBTLX is a little shorter than the average intermediate term fund 710 yrs VBTLX wont be nearly as rate sensitive due to the vast overweight of short bonds in the total market index.
