Adding more context about the cons and risks of 401k loans. In short its not free money, far from it. The funds are taken out of the market, so you stunt your 401k growth. Growth inside a 401k is tax sheltered. Growth dividends, realized capital gains in a brokerage account are taxable The interest is double taxed ultimately. The interest is of course not a gain, but extra funds taken from your paycheck. Money not going towards bills, savings, etc. The repayments are fixed. Its impossible to get your HR to stop taking it from your paycheck. So if youre in a future tight bind youre kind of screwed. If you leavelose your job for any reason before the loan is paid off, you may owe the entire loan almost immediately. And if you cannot pay then you will default and owe income tax 10 penalty. This is painful enough as is, but consider theres 0 withholding on a loan so youll now owe it all out of pocket, all while youre looking for a new job. Due to IRS and employer limits on loan amounts and frequency, you limit your ability to take another loan in the event of a true emergency.

If you take out a subsidized student loan you can put it into a high yield savings account and keep the interest and then pay it off when you graduate. I wouldnt recommend dividends because in stocks you risk your capital going down.

Well, yeah? If you could get a 2 unsecured loan, your idea would work. Thats kinda the whole basis for why equities have a higher return than fixed income given enough time. If you can get 12 over inflation on debt from governments and large companies that are extremely unlikely to default, then nobody will buy into a company unless theres a good chance itll return more than that either by returning excess revenue in the form of dividends, or by reinvesting excess revenue in order to grow in value. Since theres volatility in equities, the expected return has to be significantly higher than the risk free rate in order for it to be worthwhile. If you can get 3 guaranteed, vs 6 10 then any given shorter term has a good chance of returning less than the risk free rate, but if you can afford to leave the money invested long enough the average will be higher and its worthwhile.

it undermines the liability protection of the LLC. Can you please explain why?
deleted

You might be exposing your equity portfolio to liability from the commercial real estate when the time comes to purchase and own that real estate. A big point of an LLC is to shield your personal assets from the liabilities of the LLC. To unnecessarily put personal assets into the LLC basically defeats that point. That said, you may have another reason to put the assets in the LLC, eg, if there is some issue relating to ownership or succession planning for the equities and in that case its possible a trust might even be a better option. Of course, we dont know all the facts so an estatebusiness planning attorney may have better answers on this front.

The whole point of an LLC is to shield the LLCs owners from the actions of the LLC. If you run your business through an LLC, and the business creates a liability, then theoretically your personal assets can be protected. But it doesnt work the other way around. You cant just park assets in an LLC and have them be protected from personal liability. Say you run a business making shampoo, and your product makes peoples hair fall out. Thats a business liability. Your customers could sue the LLC and claim any assets in the LLCs name, but they may have trouble taking, say, your house or personal bank accounts. Thats what the whole idea of limited liability is for. But if you have other unrelated assets in the LLC, then those are the LLCs assets, and would be easier to reach in a civil action. Meanwhile, the protection does not work the other way. If your LLC holds 100k worth of stock, then your LLC is worth 100k. And if you own 100 of the LLC, then your LLC shares are worth 100k. And so if someone sues you, instead of taking your LLCs assets they could just take the LLC. Youve replaced one type of asset with another, with no net protection added. In practice it would probably not work exactly like that but you see my point. Anyway, your lawyers and accountants are probably happily accepting the fees they earn managing your LLCs for you. If you think theres any benefit, you should explicitly ask them what that benefit is.
deleted
I didnt mean to offend. But you asked an honest question and I gave you an honest answer. If youd rather trust your professionals, thats 100 understandable, but then why ask in the first place?

Look at it this way. You own 2 rental houses and have 100k of cash in an LLC. The owner of the LLC also owns a house and other assets directly not in an LLC. If something happens at a rental inside the LLC, his directly owned assets are protected but the assets inside the LLC are not and are fair game for taking if sued. If something happens and the owner is sued due to assets owned directly, the LLC itself and all directly owned assets are fair game. The only benefit an LLC provides is protection of directly owned assets from liabilty of assets inside the LLC. So putting a bunch of assets inside an LLC provides no real safety for those assets.

Exactly, if the OP were to hit an innercity bus, the ambulancechasing plaintiffs attorney would sue the OP, and the LLC would just be one of many assets that could be commandeered.

replies.text: Yes, the biggest growers will be removed from the smallcap index at its next annual or quarterly reconstitution. A fund that tracks the index will sell those stocks and buy new smallcap stocks. Some of those stocks will grow out of the index next time. Meanwhile, the index fund is capturing the growth of all these stocks for the time while they are part of the index. Imagine that you profit from the growth of children by selling uniform clothing to the children in an elementary school. You profit from their growth while they are students at the school. Eventually, each child graduates and you lose that customer, but the school still has 600 students and youre still profiting from all of their growth. Same thing with the companies in the index fund. The fund owns a share of their growth until theyre too big, and then sells it and buys shares of smaller companies growth.

Great question! Youre touching on an important aspect of how smallcap index ETFs work and grow over time. Lets break this down 1. Index Rebalancing Smallcap indices, like the SP SmallCap 600, are regularly rebalanced. This means that companies that grow beyond the defined market cap range are indeed removed and replaced with smaller companies. 2. Capturing Growth The idea behind smallcap indices is to capture the growth potential of smaller companies. While its true that the best performers eventually graduate out of the index, the index has benefited from their growth up to that point. 3. Continuous Cycle As some companies grow out of the index, new, potentially fastgrowing companies are added. This creates a continuous cycle of capturing growth at the smallcap level. 4. Historical Performance Historically, smallcap stocks have shown the potential for higher returns over long periods, albeit with higher volatility. This is often referred to as the smallcap effect. 5. Diversification Smallcap ETFs provide exposure to a segment of the market that behaves differently from largecaps, offering diversification benefits. 6. Growth Potential The bet, as youve correctly identified, is on the overall growth potential of smaller companies. While not all will succeed, the index aims to capture the aggregate growth of this segment. 7. Economic Factors Smallcaps can be more sensitive to economic cycles, potentially offering higher returns during economic expansions. Its worth noting that while some companies do grow out of the smallcap range, many remain within it for extended periods. The growth of the index isnt solely dependent on companies growing beyond the smallcap definition. Remember, while smallcap ETFs can offer growth potential, they also come with higher volatility and risk. Its important to consider your overall investment strategy, risk tolerance, and time horizon when deciding on asset allocation. Disclosures.

Its a bet that smaller companies have larger discount rates on their future cashflows, implying higher expected returns. If they get churned out of the index, who cares? Systemically, exposure to small cap value stocks through time has beaten the market over 30 years since dimensional implemented that research into their small cap value fund DFSVX

The ETF isnt a bet on the sector size, which i think is the point of confusion. It takes profits from companies that grow to mid caps and uses those profits to buy more small caps. Rinse and repeat. Also, some small cap ETFs use momentum, which means they wont sell a small cap thats raising in value until it stabilizes in value so they will capture a lot of the run up when a small cap grows larger. They dont sell it as soon as its not a small cap. Avantis does this.

at some point some of the top growers cross the upper market cap level and are dropped from the index and replaced with other small cap companies and you stop to benefit from the best performing companies in the index. You are making the false assumption that companies that growout of the small cap space they will continue to be the best performing companies just because they grew well in the past. If your premise was correct then someone could make an ETF that consisted only of companies that got booted from the small cap index because they grew too much. Is it just a bet that most of small companies grow the fastest and as they grow too big they are dropped because it is believed that their growth will slow down? Its not like you have to stick all your eggs in one basket. You can own a small cap ETF, a midcap ETF and a largecap ETF in a single portfolio. Different size companies perform differently in different parts of the market cycle. Smallcaps tend to be hamstrung when interest rates are high since they tend to borrow more, for instance.

Yes small cap grow into mid cap, and grow into large cap. The response to that is buy total market index fund. But I only hold large cap and mid cap. Dont think small cap is worth it. The only benefit to small cap is diversification. But its not obvious benefit. Some investors believe small cap are better value, but there are mid and large cap value stocks. Your mileage may vary.

Covered calls are easy. You just sell a call say at 145 strike and collect 390 in premium. If it goes above 145 youre obligated to sell it at 145, even if it goes to 200. But you get the 390 no matter what so it will lower your cost basis or you sell the shares. The downside is you wont capture all the upside potential of it shoots way up. Heres a good video on covered calls. Once you understand them theyre very simple. Any questions feel free to ask.

I just wanted to clarify your 2nd point (for those who are reading your message):   The  cost of revenue ($428.8M) is a part of (ie. 74% of) the operating expense of $651.9M.  You cannot add those 2 numbers together and say "That's over $1 billion..." etc.This is why if you read an official GAAP Consolidated Statement of Operations filed by any corporation, where they calculate net revenue vs. net loss, you would never see the words "Cost of Revenue" in it.  Instead, it's always presented as "Operating Expense," and the cost of sales, marketing, raw materials for solar modules, etc...  are itemized below that heading.  The partial sum of those items are what they consider as "cost of revenue."

Just finished listening to Sunnova's earnings call, and there were numerous highlights that may pertain to what we'll hear in Sunrun's earnings calls next week.   They started to see business really pick up during May this year, and their June sales + building activity has already exceeded their normal season peak activity in August of every year. They are leaning towards cash discipline, cash generation, and paying down their debt.  So much so, it affects #3 below On the call, they actually admitted they can't handle this level of growth in the business (now that Sunpower is probably going out of business).  As of now, they are pausing the addition of new dealers.  They also addressed the rumors that Sunnova was slow-paying their dealers (see point #2 above).  They are vetting and forcing all currently dealers to comply with buying domestically-made solar modules + batteries by Sept 1...  because all new solar installs will then be ITC adder-compatible, and they can generate more cash by selling those ITC credits They were a little mum about expanding their operations in CA to fill the vacuum left by Sunpower.  The CEO basically said, "we have been taking market share there," and that's it.The basic story: They want to expand, but they can't take full advantage of the situation because of their cash positions.  This probably bodes well for Sunrun in the near future, because Sunrun does more direct-sales than partnering with minor dealers, and their cash position is stable.
